By using a truncation protocol and alanine scanning, we identified Tyr-288 in the PS1 N-terminal fragment as critical for PS-dependent intramembrane proteolysis. Further mutagenesis of the 288 site identified mutants differentially affecting endoproteolysis and γ-secretase activity. The Y288F mutant was endoproteolyzed to the same extent as wild type PS but increased the amyloid β-protein 42/40 ratio by ∼75%. In contrast, the Y288N mutant was also endoproteolytically processed but was inactive in reconstituting γ-secretase in PS null cells. The Y288D mutant was deficient in both endoproteolysis and γ-secretase activity. All three mutant PS1 molecules were incorporated into γ-secretase complexes and stabilized Pen-2 in PS null cells. Thus, mutations at Tyr-288 do not affect γ-secretase complex assembly but can differentially control endoproteolysis and γ-secretase activity. γ-Secretase catalyzes the final step in the generation of the amyloid β-protein (Aβ) 1The abbreviations used are: Aβ, amyloid β-protein; APP, Alzheimer amyloid precursor protein; AICD, APP intracellular domain; PS, presenilin; NTF, N-terminal fragment; CTF, C-terminal fragment; CHAPSO, 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-2-hydroxy-1-propanesulfonic acid; Tricine, N-[2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl]glycine; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; DAPT, N-[N-(3,5-difluoro-phenacetyl)-l-alanyl]-S-phenylglycine t-butyl ester. from the transmembrane Alzheimer amyloid precursor protein (APP) in a process known as regulated intramembrane proteolysis (reviewed in Ref. 1De Strooper B. Neuron. 2003; 38: 9-12Google Scholar). Aβ is the major protein component of the amyloid deposits that neuropathologically characterize Alzheimer's disease. In parallel with γ-secretase-mediated Aβ generation, a cytosolic fragment, the APP intracellular domain (AICD), is formed. The N terminus of AICD is located 8–10 residues C-terminal to the site predicted by the γ-secretase cleavages generating Aβ40 and Aβ42 (2Sastre M. Steiner H. Fuchs K. Capell A. Multhaup G. Condron M.M. Teplow D.B. Haass C. EMBO Rep. 2001; 2: 835-841Google Scholar). This cleavage site occurring between Leu-49 and Val-50 (Aβ numbering) has been termed the ϵ site. Competition studies in vitro suggest that cleavage at the ϵ site is intimately related to γ-secretase cleavage (3Kimberly W.T. Esler W.P. Ye W. Ostaszewski B. Gao J. Diehl T. Selkoe D.J. Wolfe M.S. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 137-144Google Scholar). Accumulating evidence suggests that the PS proteins are required in order for γ-secretase cleavage to occur (4De Strooper B. Annaert W. Cupers P. Saftig P. Craessaerts K. Mumm J.S. Schroeter E.H. Schrijvers V. Wolfe M.S. Ray W.J. Goate A. Kopan R. Nature. 1999; 398: 518-522Google Scholar, 5Herreman A. Serneels L. Annaert W. Collen D. Schoonjans L. De Strooper B. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 461-462Google Scholar, 6Zhang Z. Nadeau P. Song W. Donoviel D. Yuan M. Bernstein A. Yankner B.A. Nat. Cell Biol. 2000; 2: 463-465Google Scholar). PS proteins contain 10 hydrophobic domains, 8 of which form transmembrane domains according to most current models (7Doan A. Thinakaran G. Borchelt D.R. Slunt H.H. Ratovitsky T. Podlisny M. Many substrates in addition to APP have been identified as targets for PS-dependent processing, among them the family of Notch cell surface receptors (4De Strooper B. Annaert W. Cupers P. Saftig P. Craessaerts K. Mumm J.S. Schroeter E.H. Schrijvers V. Wolfe M.S. Ray W.J. Goate A. Kopan R. Nature. 1999; 398: 518-522Google Scholar, 20Mizutani T. Taniguchi Y. Aoki T. Hashimoto N. Honjo T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 9026-9031Google Scholar). Here we used a recently developed luciferase-based reporter system (21Karlström H. Bergman A. Lendahl U. Näslund J. Lundkvist J. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 6763-6766Google Scholar, 22Struhl G. Adachi A. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 625-636Google Scholar) to define structural elements in PS1 that are critical for mediating endoproteolysis and γ-secretase complex assembly and activity. We have previously shown that PS1 NTF and CTF restore γ-secretase cleavage of the two best-known PS-controlled regulated intramembrane proteolysis substrates, APP and Notch, when co-expressed in PS-deficient cells (23Laudon H. Mathews P.M. Karlström H. Bergman A. Farmery M.R. Nixon R.A. Winblad B. Gandy S.E. Lendahl U. Lundkvist J. Näslund J. J. Neurochem. 2004; 89: 44-53Google Scholar). By using progressively truncated NTFs and alanine-scanning mutagenesis, we defined a short motif in the cytoplasmic loop juxtaposed to the endoproteolytic site that is required for γ-secretase activation. The major activity determinant of the motif was the Tyr-288 residue. Extensive mutagenesis revealed the basic biochemical characteristics of the amino acid occupying position 288 critical for restoring PS1 endoproteolysis and PS1-mediated γ-secretase activity. An analysis of the Y288F, Y288N, and Y288D mutants revealed that the capacity for endoproteolysis and γ-secretase activity can be separated, whereas the incorporation into the mature γ-secretase complex was retained. Expression Constructs—The reporter constructs that were used in the luciferase-based reporter system to monitor AICD and notch intra-cellular domain generation have been described previously (21Karlström H. Bergman A. Lendahl U. Näslund J. Lundkvist J. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 6763-6766Google Scholar, 24Taniguchi Y. Karlström H. Lundkvist J. Mizutani T. Otaka A. Vestling M. Bernstein A. Donoviel D. Lendahl U. Honjo T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 4014-4019Google Scholar). Full-length PS1 and PS1 NTFs were in the pcDNA3 backbone, and the CTF was in pcDNA3.1. The NTF constructs illustrated in Fig. 1A encode PS1 molecules truncated after amino acids Met-298 (NTF), Gly-266 (HD6stop), Glu-243 (HD5stop), Lys-216 (HD4stop), and Arg-157 (HD2stop), respectively. Mutations were introduced by site-directed mutagenesis according to the QuikChange™ protocol (Stratagene). The DNA sequence of each construct was verified using the DYEnamic ET Terminator cycle sequencing kit (Amersham Biosciences) and the ABI Prism 377 sequencer (PerkinElmer Life Sciences). PS1 constructs used for generating stable cell lines were cloned into the pCAG-IRES-Puro vector using conventional cloning procedures. Cell Culture and Transfection—Blastocyst-derived embryonic stem cells lacking PS1 and PS2 (BD8 cells) previously had been generated by immortalizing cells from PS1/PS2 double-null mice on embryonic day 3.5 (24Taniguchi Y. Karlström H. Lundkvist J. Mizutani T. Otaka A. Vestling M. Bernstein A. Donoviel D. Lendahl U. Honjo T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 4014-4019Google Scholar, 25Donoviel D.B. Hadjantonakis A.-K. Ikeda M. Zheng H. St George-Hyslop P. Bernstein A. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 2801-2810Google Scholar). The BD8 cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 1 mm sodium pyruvate, 2.4 mm l-glutamine, 0.1 mm β-mercaptoethanol, and nonessential amino acids. Stably transfected BD8 cells were maintained in medium supplemented with 1 μg/ml puromycin (Sigma). All of the transfections were carried out using LipofectAMINE Plus according to the manufacturer's instructions (Invitrogen). Luciferase-based Reporter Assays and Immunoblotting—Transfections for the luciferase-based reporter assays were carried out in 24-well tissue culture plates essentially as described previously (23Laudon H. Mathews P.M. Karlström H. Bergman A. Farmery M.R. Nixon R.A. Winblad B. Gandy S.E. Lendahl U. Lundkvist J. Näslund J. J. Neurochem. 2004; 89: 44-53Google Scholar). Cells were lysed in 100 μl of lysis buffer/well (10 mm Tris, pH 8, 1 mm EDTA, 150 mm NaCl, and 0.65% Nonidet P-40), and luciferase activity was monitored luminometrically after the addition of luciferin and ATP (BioThema). The β-galactosidase activities of the cell lysates were determined to equalize for differences in transfection efficiencies. Arbitrary β-galactosidase-normalized luminescence units are presented as percent activity compared with wild type PS1 response. For immunoblotting, cell lysates were briefly sonicated and resolved on 10–20% Tricine gels. Proteins were transferred to nitrocellulose membranes that were subsequently probed with appropriate antibodies. The immunoblots were developed using horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies and ECL substrate (Pierce). Antibodies—The antibodies used for co-immunoprecipitations of PS1 were polyclonal antibody Ab14 raised against the N terminus of PS1 (18Seeger M. Nordstedt C. Petanceska S. Kovacs D.M. Gouras G.K. Hahne S. Fraser P. Levesque L. Czernik A.J. St George-Hyslop P. Sisodia S.S. Thinakaran G. Tanzi R.E. Greengard P. Gandy S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 5090-5094Google Scholar) and monoclonal antibody MAB5232 (Chemicon), which recognizes PS1 CTF. For immunoblotting of PS1, monoclonal antibody NT1 directed toward the N terminus (26Mathews P.M. Cataldo A.M. Kao B.H. Rudnicki A.G. Qin X. Yang J.L. Jiang Y. Picciano M. Hulette C. Lippa C.F. Bird T.D. Nochlin D. Walter J. Haass C. Levesque L. Fraser P.E. Andreadis A. Nixon R.A. Mol. Med. 2000; 6: 878-891Google Scholar) and MAB5232 were used. Nicastrin was immunoprecipitated using polyclonal antibody N1660 (Sigma), and Aph-1 was immunoprecipitated with polyclonal antibody H2D (Calbiochem). Polyclonal antibody 369 (27Buxbaum J.D. Gandy S.E. Cicchetti P. Ehrlich M.E. Czernik A.J. Fracasso R.P. Ramabhadran T.V. Unterbeck A.J. Greengard P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 6003-6006Google Scholar) and monoclonal antibody C1/6.1 (28Mathews P.M. Jiang Y. Schmidt S.D. Grbovic O.M. Mercken M. Nixon R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 36415-36424Google Scholar), which were both raised against the C-terminal end of APP, were used for immunoprecipitations. Polyclonal antibody UD1 was used for immunoblotting of Pen-2 (29Bergman A. Hansson E. Pursglove S.E. Farmery M.R. Lannfelt L. Lendahl U. Lundkvist J. Näslund J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 16744-16753Google Scholar). Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay—Transient transfections were performed in 6-well plates in triplicates. Per well, cells were transiently transfected with 500 ng of C99-encoding vector. Cells were cultured for 48 h in 0.75 ml of Opti-MEM supplemented with 5% fetal bovine serum. Cell media were flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen and subjected to sandwich enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay measurements essentially as described previously (28Mathews P.M. Jiang Y. Schmidt S.D. Grbovic O.M. Mercken M. Nixon R.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 36415-36424Google Scholar). Co-immunoprecipitations—Co-immunoprecipitations were performed on lysates from stably transfected cells. Cells were cultured to confluency in a 6-well format. Per well, cells were lysed in 0.5 ml of coimmunoprecipitation buffer (50 mm Hepes, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl, 2 mm EDTA, protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Applied Science), and 1% CHAPSO) and briefly sonicated. Lysates were subjected to ultracentrifugation (100,000 × g, 20 min). The CHAPSO-soluble supernatant was incubated with primary antibody (dilution 1:300) overnight, and proteins were pulled down with a mixture of proteins A- and G-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences). Pre-immune serum was used as negative control. Immunoprecipitated proteins were resolved on 10–20% Tricine gels (Invitrogen), transferred to nitrocellulose membranes, and detected by immunoblotting as described above. Subcellular Fractionation—PS-deficient BD8 cells and BD8 cells stably expressing wild type or mutant PS1 were cultured in 10-cm plates to near confluency. Per cell line, the cells from two plates were harvested and homogenized in ice-cold homogenization buffer (130 mm KCl, 25 mm NaCl, 1 mm EGTA, 25 mm Tris, pH 7.4) supplemented with protease inhibitor mixture. Lysates were cleared by centrifugation at 1,000 × g for 10 min. The supernatants were overlaid onto the top of a step gradient consisting of 1 ml each of 30, 25, 20, 15, 12.5, 10, 7.5, and 5% iodixanol (OptiPrep reagent, Axis-Shield PoC AS) diluted in homogenization buffer. After 90 min of centrifugation at 126,000 × g (Beckman), fractions were collected from the top of the gradient. After dilution, membranes were pelleted by centrifugation at 20,000 × g for 20 min. Proteins were resolved on 4–20% Tris-glycine gels (Criterion, Bio-Rad), transferred to nitrocellulose membranes, and detected by immunoblotting as described above. Co-expression of C-terminally Truncated NTF and Native CTF—We have recently shown that co-expression of the PS1 NTF and CTF can functionally substitute for the expression of the full-length molecule in mammalian PS null cells (23Laudon H. Mathews P.M. Karlström H. Bergman A. Farmery M.R. Nixon R.A. Winblad B. Gandy S.E. Lendahl U. Lundkvist J. Näslund J. J. Neurochem. 2004; 89: 44-53Google Scholar). Based on this knowledge, we designed an experimental protocol where truncated NTFs were co-expressed with wild type CTF in a PS-deficient cellular background. We used blastocyst-derived mouse embryonic stem cells lacking PS1 and PS2 (25Donoviel D.B. Hadjantonakis A.-K. Ikeda M. Zheng H. St George-Hyslop P. Bernstein A. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 2801-2810Google Scholar) and a luciferase-based reporter system that quantifies intramembrane processing (21Karlström H. Bergman A. Lendahl U. Näslund J. Lundkvist J. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 6763-6766Google Scholar) to study γ-secretase cleavage of APP and Notch. To this end, we used truncated versions of APP and Notch, which mimic β-secretase-processed APP (C99) and ligand-activated and ectodomain-shedded Notch1 (ΔEN1) (30Schroeter E.H. Kisslinger J.A. Kopan R. Nature. 1998; 393: 382-386Google Scholar). C99 and ΔEN1 both represent direct substrates for PS-dependent intramembrane processing. An array of successively truncated NTFs (Fig. 1A) was transfected into PS null cells together with wild type CTF (Fig. 1B). Of the fragments tested, only the native NTF was able to mediate γ-secretase processing of C99 and ΔEN1. Expression of the NTFs was confirmed by immunoblotting (Fig. 1B, lower panel). Thus, residues 267–298 in the cytoplasmic loop of the NTF are critical for rescuing γ-secretase activity in PS-deficient cells. To demarcate the γ-secretase-activating domain in the 32-residue sequence defined above, an additional array of truncated NTF variants was generated (Fig. 1C). These NTFs were co-transfected with native CTF, and γ-secretase cleavage of C99 and ΔEN1 was measured (Fig. 1D). PS1-controlled γ-secretase activity was dramatically decreased when PS1 residues 284–288 were deleted, indicating that a key sequence is located in hydrophobic domain 7 between residues Pro-284 and Tyr-288. This PALIY motif is situated just N-terminal to the physiological endoproteolysis site (Fig. 1A), which is mapped to a region positioned between residues Thr-291 and Ala-299 (31Podlisny M.B. Citron M. Amarante P. Sherrington R. Xia W. Zhang J. Diehl T. Levesque G. Fraser P. Haass C. Koo E.H.M. Seubert P. St George-Hyslop P. Teplow D.B. Selkoe D.J. Neurobiol. Dis. 1997; 3: 325-337Google Scholar). Steady-state levels of the expressed NTF variants were corroborated by immunoblotting (Fig. 1D, lower panel). It is worth noting that this region is important for PS-mediated γ-secretase processing of both C99 and ΔEN1, implying that this motif may be critical not only for APP and Notch but possibly also for most or all of the other PS-controlled regulated intramembrane proteolysis substrates. To more precisely assess the residues in the PALIY motif critical for mediating the γ-secretase-activating effect, alanine mutants were generated in the PS1 full-length protein. Mutant PS1 proteins were transfected into the PS-deficient cells, and γ-secretase cleavage of C99 and ΔEN1 was recorded. The Y288A mutant exhibited a pronounced reduction in γ-secretase, rescuing activity for both C99 and ΔEN1 (73 and 58% reduction, respectively) (Fig. 1E). The effect of exchanging the other residues in the activating element for alanine was less apparent on C99 (16, 26, and 22% reduction for P284A, L286A, and I287A, respectively) (Fig. 1E). The results for ΔEN1 were somewhat different compared with C99, and here in fact, there was a small increase for P284A and I287A (10 and 8%, respectively) (Fig. 1E). Importantly, the Ala mutations did not impair endoproteolysis of the mutant PS1 holoprotein (Fig. 1E, lower panel). However, to exclude the possibility that changes in endoproteolysis too small to be detected by immunoblotting account for the Y288A effect observed above, Ala mutations were also introduced into the NTF. When expressed together with wild type CTF, these NTF mutants showed a pattern similar to the mutant full-length proteins on rescue of γ-secretase processing (Fig. 1F). In contrast to the decreased C99 processing for full-length PS1 mutants P284A, L286A, and I287A, when introduced into the NTF, these mutations increased γ-secretase cleavage of C99 with 12, 4, and 38%, respectively. Importantly, the Y288A substitution reduced the γ-secretase-rescuing effect with ∼50–60%. Taken together, these data suggest that Tyr-288 is the main determinant of the PALIY motif for sustaining γ-secretase. Apparently, an Ala mutation in position 288 of the activating element disrupts γ-secretase activity by some mechanism other than inhibition of PS1 endoproteolysis. Moreover, an NTF ending at residue 287, thereby lacking Tyr-288, did not rescue γ-secretase activity when co-expressed with CTF (data not shown). Thus, Tyr-288 in PS1 is crucial for restoring γ-secretase activity in PS null cells. Site-directed Mutagenesis of Tyr-288 —To obtain a more detailed view on the characteristics of the residue occupying position 288, we subjected this residue to mutagenesis in PS1 full-length protein and in the NTF. We used the luciferase assay to study C99 processing when these mutants were transiently expressed in PS-deficient cells. Using this qualitative approach, we could show that hydrophobic and bulky residues in position 288 of the full-length protein or NTF restored γ-secretase processing of C99 (Fig. 2, A and B). For some mutants, intramembrane proteolysis of C99 was considerably enhanced, in particular when the mutation was introduced in the NTF. For example, the Y288M and Y288W mutations increased γ-secretase activity with 70 and 28%, respectively (Fig. 2B). Polar and charged residues were less well tolerated in the 288 position. C99 processing was in some cases dramatically reduced when these mutants (e.g. Y288D, Y288N) were expressed (Fig. 2, A and B). The PALIY motif and the Tyr-288 residue are located close to the PS endoproteolysis site, and because the functional significance of PS endoproteolysis with regard to γ-secretase activity remains unclear, we assayed the Tyr-288 mutants for endoproteolysis. Some of the mutants tested, Y288D, Y288E, and Y288K, also had a profound negative effect on endoproteolysis of PS1 (Fig. 2C). Expression of PS1 Tyr-288 Mutants on a Null Background—We selected three mutants, Y288F, Y288N, and Y288D, for stable expression in the PS-deficient BD8 cells. The Y288F mutant restored C99 processing to the same extent as the PS1 wild type molecule (Fig. 3A). In contrast, neither the Y288N nor the Y288D mutant mediated γ-secretase cleavage of the C99 reporter molecule (Fig. 3A). Because the reporter assay used here does not differentiate between the γ- and ϵ-cleavage of the substrates, we wanted to directly analyze γ-secretase cleavage of C99 by measuring Aβ40 and Aβ42 secreted into medium. Consistent with the findings for AICD formation, expression of the Y288N and Y288D mutants did not result in any detectable Aβ40 or Aβ42 secretion (data not shown). Interestingly, expression of the intramembrane proteolysis-active Y288F mutant resulted in an ∼75% increase in the Aβ42/40 ratio compared with the wild type PS1 molecule (Fig. 3B). Tyr-288 Mutants and γ-Secretase Complex Assembly—The failure of the Y288N and Y288D mutants to restore PS-mediated intramembrane proteolysis in PS null cells could possibly be related to misincorporation of the mutants into fully assembled and mature γ-secretase complexes. Therefore, we performed immunoblotting experiments of CHAPSO lysates prepared from the stable cell lines (Fig. 4). In lysates, NTF and CTF can be clearly visualized from BD8 cells stably expressing wild type PS1 (panel I, lane 2). In addition, the expression of PS1 in PS-deficient cells leads to stabilization of Pen-2 as shown previously (29Bergman A. Hansson E. Pursglove S.E. Farmery M.R. Lannfelt L. Lendahl U. Lundkvist J. Näslund J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 16744-16753Google Scholar, 32Steiner H. Winkler E. Edbauer D. Prokop S. Basset G. Yamasaki A. Kostka M. Haass C. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 39062-39065Google Scholar). As suggested from the luciferase experiments, the biochemical phenotype of the Y288F mutant resembled that of the wild type molecule (panel I, lane 3). As shown above using transient transfections, endoproteolysis of the Y288D mutant is severely impaired also in stably transfected cells (panel I, lane 4). Interestingly, the Y288N mutant, which cannot restore γ-secretase processing of C99, is endoproteolytically processed to a level almost comparable with wild type PS1. Expression of both Y288D and Y288N leads to the stabilization of Pen-2, indirectly implying that the mutants were incorporated into mature, albeit non-functional, γ-secretase complexes. Correct complex incorporation of the mutants was further corroborated using co-immunoprecipitations. The CTF was coprecipitated with the NTF for all of the stably expressed PS1 variants, albeit very little for the endoproteolysis-defective Y288D mutant (panel III, lanes 2–5). It is worth noting that Pen-2 associates and apparently co-precipitates with full-length Y288D (panel III, lane 4), in agreement with a previous report showing association between Pen-2 and the D257A and D385A PS1 mutants (33Nyabi O. Bentahir M. Horré K. Herreman A. Gottardi-Litell N. Van Broeckhoven C. Merchiers P. Spittaels K. Annaert W. De Strooper B. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 43430-43436Google Scholar). The NTF was associated with the CTF in reciprocal immunoprecipitations (panel IV, lanes 2–5). Immunoprecipitations against nicastrin and Aph-1 showed very similar immunostaining patterns when probing for the NTF and CTF (panels V and VI, lanes 2–5). The cleavage-compromised Y288D mutant associated with both nicastrin (panel V, lane 4) and Aph-1 (panel VI, lane 4) under these conditions. Complex assembly of the mutants was further investigated by subjecting membranes from the stable cell lines to iodixanol gradient fractionation (Fig. 5). This method allows separation of ER-rich vesicles from Golgi- and post-Golgi-rich vesicles (34Campbell W.A. Iskandar M.-K. Reed M.L.O. Xia W. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 3372-3379Google Scholar). We corroborated the separation between ER and Golgi by using the ER marker KDEL and medial-Golgi marker GM130, respectively. As previously shown by many groups (35Edbauer D. Winkler E. Haass C. Steiner H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 8666-8671Google Scholar, 36Leem J.-Y. Vijayan S. Han P. Cai D. Machura M. Lopes K.O. Veselits M.L. Xu H. Thinakaran G. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 19236-19240Google Scholar, 37Tomita T. Katayama R. Takikawa R. Iwatsubo T. FEBS Lett. 2002; 520: 117-121Google Scholar, 38Yang D.-S. Tandon A. Chen F. Yu G. Arawaka S. Hasegawa H. Duthie M. Schmidt S.D. Ramabhadran T.V. Nixon R.A. Mathews P.M. Gandy S.E. Mount H.T.J. St George-Hyslop P. Fraser P.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 28135-28142Google Scholar), nicastrin is not trafficked beyond the early Golgi and does not reach full maturation in PS null cells (panel A). Moreover, as reported previously (29Bergman A. Hansson E. Pursglove S.E. Farmery M.R. Lannfelt L. Lendahl U. Lundkvist J. Näslund J. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 16744-16753Google Scholar), Pen-2 is sequestered in the ER and destined for ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation in the absence of PS (panel A). In BD8 cells stably expressing wild type PS1, ER retention of Pen-2 was released and fully glycosylated nicastrin could be found in Golgi-rich fractions (panel B). Stable expression of the Y288N and Y288D mutants in BD8 cells resulted in almost identical subcellular distributions of Pen-2 and mature nicastrin for the mutants and wild type PS1 (panels B–D). It is notable that the full-length Y288D and Y288N mutants are distributed to Golgi-like fractions that overlap with fractions containing only NTF from the wild type molecule (compare panels C and D with B). In contrast to the wild type PS protein, which is mainly found in its cleaved form in Golgi-like fractions, the mutant full-length molecules are apparently distributed to post-ER compartments. This suggests that blocked endoproteolysis does not prevent the mutant molecules from being trafficked normally. In summary, exchanging Tyr-288 for Asn or Asp, thus rendering the PS1 molecul

For any given metabolic pathway, isotope redistribution coefficients (aij) that characterize the specific derivation of each hydrogen atom can be defined. By using quantitative deuterium NMR, the redistribution of deuterium at natural abundance in lactic acid produced by the bacterial fermentation of glucose has been determined for each non-labile hydrogen atom of glucose or water and the hydrogen atoms of lactic acid. Distinct differences are observed in the lactic acid isolated from Lactococcus lactis and Leuconostoc mesenteroides that can be interpreted in terms of the different fermentative pathways used. Specifically, the affiliations observed between the H1, H3, and H4 positions of glucose with methyl and hydroxymethylene of lactic acid can give quantitative information on whether the glycolytic or the reductive pentose-phosphate pathway was involved in glucose catabolism. For any given metabolic pathway, isotope redistribution coefficients (aij) that characterize the specific derivation of each hydrogen atom can be defined. By using quantitative deuterium NMR, the redistribution of deuterium at natural abundance in lactic acid produced by the bacterial fermentation of glucose has been determined for each non-labile hydrogen atom of glucose or water and the hydrogen atoms of lactic acid. Distinct differences are observed in the lactic acid isolated from Lactococcus lactis and Leuconostoc mesenteroides that can be interpreted in terms of the different fermentative pathways used. Specifically, the affiliations observed between the H1, H3, and H4 positions of glucose with methyl and hydroxymethylene of lactic acid can give quantitative information on whether the glycolytic or the reductive pentose-phosphate pathway was involved in glucose catabolism. An intriguing aspect of the chemistry of living organisms is that numerous examples exist where different reaction schemes have evolved to perform essentially the same chemical operation. A well known example in microorganisms is the existence of several routes by which fermentable substrates are catabolized in anaerobic environments. Two principal routes exploited are glycolysis and the reductive pentose-phosphate (RPP) 1The abbreviations used are: RPP, reductive pentose-phosphate; G6P, glucose-6-phosphate; G3P, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate; KIE, kinetic isotope effect; HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography; Cf, conversion factor; nRH, number of totally protiated molecules; nRD, monodenterated number of molecules. pathway. Essentially, each pathway aims to extract energy as ATP and carbon skeletons for synthesis. Redox balance and reductant power, namely as NAD+/NADH or NADP+/NADPH, requires oxidant activity early in the pathway, and this needs to be regenerated to maintain energy balance and catabolize further substrate. This is achieved via a series of terminal reductase reactions, the precise nature of which varies with the organism. Both the glycolytic and RPP pathways occur in members of the industrially important group of bacteria that ferment sugars to lactic acid, the lactic acid bacteria. These bacteria exploit the reduction of pyruvate to lactate for NAD+ regeneration, with lactic acid accumulating in the medium. This acidification has an important role in many food preparation processes (1Vedamuthu E. J. Dairy Sci. 1994; 77: 2725-2737Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (85) Google Scholar). Growing anaerobically, lactic acid bacteria may be homofermentative, producing essentially 2 mol of lactate/mol of glucose by glycolysis, as is the case for Lactococcus (Lc.) lactis (2Cocaign-Bousquet M. Garrigues C. Loubière P. Lindley N. Antonie Leeuwenhoek. 1996; 70: 253-267Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar). Alternatively, as with Leuconostoc (Ln.) mesenteroides, the bacterium is heterofermentative, producing 1 mol of lactate/mol of glucose, with the remainder of the glucose skeleton being catabolized to various other products, including carbon dioxide, ethanol, and acetate (3Schmitt P. Diviès C. Cardona R. Appl. Microbiol. Biotechnol. 1992; 36: 679-683Crossref Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Under certain genetic and/or environmental conditions, some lactic acid bacteria can also accumulate formate and the important flavor compounds diacetyl and acetoin (4Monnet C. Aymes F. Corrieu G. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 2000; 66: 5518-5520Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar, 5Schmitt P. Diviès C. J. Ferm. Bioeng. 1991; 71: 72-74Crossref Scopus (25) Google Scholar). During fermentation, the hydrogen in the products is derived either from the sugar substrate or from the medium. The use of 3H or highly enriched 2H tracers has largely established these origins. However, it has been shown that the isotopic redistribution in 2H (D) at natural abundance in products of fermentation can be quantitatively described using quantitative 2H NMR (6Pionnier S. Zhang B.-L. Anal. Biochem. 2002; 307: 138-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar, 7Pionnier S. Robins R. Zhang B.-L. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2003; 51: 2076-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 8Robins R. Billault I. Duan J.-R. Guiet S. Pionnier S. Zhang B.-L. Phytochem. Rev. 2003; 2: 87-102Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar). Thus, a transfer matrix can be defined that links the different isotopic contents (D/H)i at the various positions i of the product to the isotopic content (D/H)j at each position j of the fermented substrate and to (D/H)m, the isotopic content of the fermentation medium (7Pionnier S. Robins R. Zhang B.-L. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2003; 51: 2076-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 9Zhang B.-L. Yunianta Martin M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 16023-16029Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) as shown in Equation 1, [D/H]i=[A][D/H]k(Eq. 1) where [(D/H)]i and [D/H]k are the column vectors of the site-specific natural isotopic ratios of the product and the substrate and [A] the matrix composed of the redistribution coefficients. The matrix can be expanded as shown in Equation 2, (D/H)i=aim(D/H)m+∑jaij(D/H)j=∑kaik(D/H)k(Eq. 2) where (D/H)i is the isotopic ratio at position i of the product, (D/H)m is the isotopic ratio of the medium, and (D/H)j is the isotopic ratio at site j of the substrate. The terms aim and aij are isotope redistribution coefficients, m,j ϵ{k}. By defining the set of values for the matrix [A], the isotopic connection between the substrate and product molecule is defined, giving a quantitative description of the derivation of the deuterium atoms. Intrinsic to this description is the summated effect of the biochemical reactions involved and their kinetic isotope effects (KIEs). Each individual aij will reflect the mechanism of the individual reactions acting on each position j in the substrate linked to different positions i in the product. Thus, the KIEs will reflect the extent to which selection against (or for, in rarer cases) a heavy isotope has occurred at individual sites in the product, leading to a non-statistical distribution of 2H in the population of monodeuterated isotopomers within the final product (8Robins R. Billault I. Duan J.-R. Guiet S. Pionnier S. Zhang B.-L. Phytochem. Rev. 2003; 2: 87-102Crossref Scopus (41) Google Scholar). Because Lc. lactis and Ln. mesenteroides exploit different pathways for the catabolism of glucose, it can be anticipated that the redistribution coefficients aim and aij ought to differ for the methyl (CH3) and hydroxymethylene (CH(OH)) of lactic acid, depending on the catabolic route by which it was produced. Essentially, these two pathways differ in three key respects (Fig. 1): 1) in the metabolism of glucose-6-phosphate (G6P). Glycolysis provides two equivalent units of triose, derived from C1-C2-C3 and C4-C5-C6 of glucose, whereas RPP provides a single unit derived from C4-C5-C6; 2) in glycolysis the reductant is exclusively NADH, whereas in Ln. mesenteroides the RPP pathway can produce both NADH and NADPH; and 3) although the pathways converge at the triose unit, each producing glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (G3P), which follows a common metabolism to pyruvate, NAD+ is regenerated by the reduction of pyruvate to l-lactate in Lc. lactis and to d-lactate in Ln. mesenteroides. l-lactate dehydrogenase (EC1.1.1.27) and d-lactate dehydrogenase (EC1.1.1.28) both exclusively use NADH as cofactor (10Dennis D. Kaplan N.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1960; 235: 810-818Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) but are mechanistically dissimilar (11Taguchi H. Ohta T. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 12588-12594Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In this report, it is shown that the isotopic redistribution in 2H between glucose and lactic acid isolated from distinct biological origins differs markedly and that these differences can be correlated to the fermentation pathway used. Materials—d-Glucose was obtained from Prolabo. Specifically labeled glucose (all at 98 atom %) was obtained from the following sources: [1-2H]glucose, [6,6′-2H2]glucose (Euriso-Top, Gif-sur-Yvette, France); [2-2H]glucose (Cambridge Isotope Labs., Andover, MA); [3-2H]glucose, [4-2H]glucose (OMICRON Biochemicals Inc., South Bend, IN). D2O (99.98 atom %) was obtained from Euriso-Top. Components of the culture medium were obtained as follows: tryptone, yeast extract (autolytic) (Biokar Diagnostics); casein-meat peptone (Labogros); soya-flour peptone (prepared using papain), sodium glycerophosphate (Merck); ascorbic acid, MgSO4 (Sigma). The same supply of each component was used for all fermentations. Bacterial Cultures—Lactococcus lactis subsp. lactis biovar diacetylactis strain B7/2147 was obtained from the Collection of Lactic Acid Bacteria (Institute of Food Research, Norwich, UK: collection B7/2147). Leuconostoc mesenteroides mesenteroides strain 19D was obtained from the collection of the Laboratoire de Microbiologie Alimentaire Industrielle (ENITIAA, Nantes, France). Both strains were stored at –80 °C in M17 medium (12Terzaghi B. Sandine W. Appl. Microbiol. 1975; 29: 807-813Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) with 15% (v/v) glycerol. Culture Conditions—Routine culture was carried out in 600 ml of M17 medium (12Terzaghi B. Sandine W. Appl. Microbiol. 1975; 29: 807-813Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) in a 1-liter-capacity autoclavable vessel (Celstir) fitted with a pH probe, a peristaltic pump for pH regulation, and a sample port. M17 medium (490 ml of a 1.2-fold concentration) adjusted to pH 6.3 (2 m HCl) was sterilized in situ (30 min; 121 °C; 1 bar). A filter-sterilized solution of glucose (30 g, 167 mmol, in 100 ml H2O) was added as well as 10 ml of bacterial starter culture (M17 medium). Fermentation was anaerobic, stirred (120 rpm) at 30 °C. Acidity was maintained constant at pH 6.0 ± 0.1 by the pH electrode-regulated addition of aliquots of NaOH (2 m). In initial experiments, lactate accumulation was followed by HPLC. Subsequently, it was monitored by gravimetric determination of NaOH consumption. Fermentation was terminated when constant weight was attained and the complete consumption of glucose was verified by HPLC and/or 1H NMR (13Silvestre V. Goupry S. Trierweiler M. Robins R. Akoka S. Anal. Chem. 2001; 73: 1862-1868Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). Typically, Lc. lactis took about 48 h and Ln. mesenteroides about 72 h. Supernatant was recovered by centrifugation (5445 g; 10 min; 4 °C) and kept at –20 °C. To follow the affiliation between each position in the substrate, glucose, and each position in the product, lactic acid, a trace quantity of specifically enriched glucose was added to the fermentation medium. Typically, 8–15 mg (±0.1 mg) was added to 30.0 g (±0.1 g) d-glucose, giving ∼3–5-fold natural abundance (∼0.06%). At this level, the NMR properties of the molecule remain unaltered. Following acidification to pH 2.2 (18 m H2SO4) and filtration, the volume was reduced by rotary evaporation to about half (in vacuo, <50 °C). Activated carbon (4 g) was added and rotation continued (atmospheric pressure, 40 °C, 2 h), after which the solution was filtered and further evaporated to about 100 ml. NaCl (2 g) was then added and dissolved. Lactic acid was recovered by exhaustive extraction with butan-2-one/diisopropyl ether (80/20) presaturated with water (14Zhang B.-L. Fallourd V. Role C. Martin G. Bioorg. Chem. 2003; 31: 227-236Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar). Following agitation with an equal volume, the mixture was left at least 90 min to achieve full phase separation. Extraction was repeated five times and the organic phases pooled. Solvent was evaporated (in vacuo, 50 °C) to leave a viscous honey-colored solution of lactic acid in water. The lactic acid recovered, determined by HPLC or 1H NMR, was between 85 and 95% maximum theoretical yield. Purity was confirmed by 1H NMR. Residual water content was determined by HPLC on suitably diluted samples. In some samples, water content was determined by Karl-Fischer titration. Quantification of Lactic Acid—Lactic acid was quantified by HPLC using a Supelcogel C-610H column (30 cm × 7.8 mm; Supelco) eluted at 30 °C with H3PO4 (0.1%) at 0.5 ml·min–1 (Agilent 1100 pump). Samples were diluted between 100–1000-fold, and 20 μl was injected per analysis. Double detection was used in series, UV (Agilent 1050) at 210 nm for lactic acid and RI (Iota 2) for glucose. 2H NMR Spectroscopy—The 2H NMR spectra were recorded with a Brucker DPX 400 spectrometer operating at 61.4 MHz and fitted with a 19F field frequency locking device. The T1 values were measured by using an inversion recovery sequence with 12 inversion time values ranging from 5 ms to 6 s and calculated using the T1 calculation software provided. The repetition time (1.25 s, = 5 × longest T1) was set accordingly. Acquisition parameters: number of scans, 6000; sweep width, 1197 Hz; acquisition time, 0.6 s; delay, 0.6 s; pulse (90°), 21 μs; T = 323 K and broadband 1H decoupling. Sample preparation: ∼2.0gof extract (containing ∼1.6–1.9 g lactic acid in water) and 1.0 g of internal reference were mixed in a sample vial with C6F6 (50 μl, lock). Exact quantities were recorded. The sample was filtered and introduced into a 10-mm NMR tube. Three to five spectra were recorded for each sample and an exponential multiplication associated with a line broadening of 2 Hz was used. The quantitative calculation of the areas under the peaks was performed using a curve-fitting algorithm (PERCH Solutions Ltd., FIN-70211, Kuopio, Finland). The (D/H)i ratios for each spectrum were calculated from Equation 3, (DH)i=(PrefPi)(mrefms×Fs)(MsMref)(SiSref)(DH)ref(Eq. 3) where Pi and Pref are the stoichiometric numbers of hydrogens in site i and in the reference. Si and Sref are the surface areas of the signal. MS, mS, and Mref are respectively the molecular weight and mass of the sample and the reference used, and Fs is the correction factor for the water content of the sample. The internal reference (ref) was N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylurea for which the isotopic ratio, (D/H)ref, was calibrated on the V.SMOW scale (15Gonfiantini R. Stichler W. Rozanski K. International Atomic Energy Agency, Standards and Intercomparison Materials for Stable Isotopes of Light Elements. International Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna1995: 13-29Google Scholar). Lactic acid has two non-equivalent hydrogen positions: the methyl, with three non-exchangeable hydrogens, and the hydroxymethylene, with one non-exchangeable hydrogen. Glucose, monodeuterated at site 1, 2, 3, or 4 or bideuterated at 6-pro-R and 6-pro-S (6,6′ will be used to designate the mean of these two positions), was used to analyze the isotopic transfer coefficients. [5-2H]Glucose was not used because H5 is lost to the medium during the action of phosphopyruvate hydratase (EC4.2.1.11) and will not be transferred to lactic acid by either organism (Figs. 2 and 3). Glucose from corn (Zea mays) was used as reference, and the natural abundance (D/H)i was determined for each hydrogen position (16Zhang B.-L. Billault I. Li X.-B. Mabon F. Remaud G. Martin M. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2002; 50: 1574-1580Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). Because (D/H)i is a linear function of (D/H)j or (D/H)m (Equation 1), isotope redistribution coefficients aij can be established using only two (D/H)i values and their corresponding (D/H)j or (D/H)m values. Thus, the affiliation was measured at natural abundance and ata3–5-fold site-specific enrichment. These data show that the transfer of deuterium from the glucose to l-lactic acid is site-specific and varies with the position j of the substrate. From the data in Table I, a set of linear equations is obtained as shown in Equations 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. Isotope transfer coefficients for (D/H)CH3 from (D/H)3 and (D/H)4, and for (D/H)CH from (D/H)1, (D/H)2, (D/H)3, and (D/H)6,6′ are not significant. Thus, the affiliations of the CH3 with the positions 1, 2, and 6,6′ are all strong, whereas negligible transfer from 3 or 4 occurs. In terms of the formation of the intermediate common to these two end products, pyruvic acid (Fig. 2), the values of aij and the Cf values for (D/H)i,CH3 are markedly consistent with those previously reported for the glycolytic catabolism of glucose to ethanol and glycerol (6Pionnier S. Zhang B.-L. Anal. Biochem. 2002; 307: 138-146Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar, 7Pionnier S. Robins R. Zhang B.-L. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2003; 51: 2076-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 17Zhang B.-L. Buddrus S. Martin M. Bioorg. Chem. 2000; 28: 1-15Crossref Scopus (20) Google Scholar). This indicates that the affiliation pattern and isotopic effects in glycolysis are relatively similar between the bacterium Lc. lactis and the mixed yeast culture (Saccharomyces crevasse and Saccharomyces bayanus) used by Pionnier et al. (7Pionnier S. Robins R. Zhang B.-L. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2003; 51: 2076-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). There are, however, a number of quantitative differences. Theoretically, deuterium at the H1 or H6,6′ positions of glucose should be transferred to the CH3 of ethanol, glycerol, and lactic acid without loss. Whereas some loss of the H1 and effectively 100% incorporation of the H6,6′ was observed in Saccharomyces metabolism (7Pionnier S. Robins R. Zhang B.-L. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2003; 51: 2076-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 9Zhang B.-L. Yunianta Martin M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 16023-16029Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar), the situation is reversed in lactic acid formation, with the H6,6′ incorporated to a lesser extent than the H1. These differences probably reflect differences in glucose utilization for other metabolic processes. In both cases, however, the degree of transfer for H2 is lower than for H1 (65–75%), reflecting some loss from this position during the intramolecular rearrangement of G6P to fructose-6-phosphate (Fig. 2, step 2). This is in good agreement with the known leakiness of the intramolecular transfer during isomerization (9Zhang B.-L. Yunianta Martin M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 16023-16029Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar, 18Liemans V. Malaisse-Lagae F. Willem R. Malaisse W. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1989; 998: 111-117Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 19Malaisse W. Malaisse-Lagae F. Liemans V. Ottinger R. Willem R. Mol. Cell. Biochem. 1990; 93: 153-165Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). The role of the medium in supplying hydrogen is also similar for all three products, although the am,CH3 values for lactic acid (0.33) and glycerol (0.52, 0.44) are higher than that for ethanol (0.18). A value of 0.33 for lactic acid is compatible with the overall introduction of at least one mol of hydrogen from the medium into the CH3 per mol of product. This can originate from the activity of pyruvate kinase (EC2.7.1.40) or during hexose-P isomerization (Fig. 2). The hydrogen at the CH(OH) of l-lactic acid is introduced at the terminal step of biosynthesis by the NADH-dependent enzyme l-lactate dehydrogenase (EC1.1.1.27), which is directly comparable with the last step in the formation of ethanol, acetaldehyde reduction, and the reduction of dihydroxyacetone phosphate to glycerol-1-P. Only the hydrogen at the glucose-H4 position is linked to CH(OH), with a transfer coefficient of 0.12. This, as previously demonstrated, indicates the transfer of the glucose-H4 to NAD+ by the action of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (phosphorylating) (EC1.2.1.12) (Fig. 2) and the reinsertion of this hydrogen because of the reductase activities. The extent of this transfer is extremely comparable in the biosynthesis of lactate (0.12), ethanol (0.18), and glycerol (0.20) (7Pionnier S. Robins R. Zhang B.-L. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2003; 51: 2076-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 17Zhang B.-L. Buddrus S. Martin M. Bioorg. Chem. 2000; 28: 1-15Crossref Scopus (20) Google Scholar). The other major source of the hydrogen introduced at CH(OH) during the reductase step is water, for which a large transfer coefficient is found (0.66), as reported for ethanol (0.78) and for glycerol (0.54) (7Pionnier S. Robins R. Zhang B.-L. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2003; 51: 2076-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). A value of Cf <1 can arise either by a dilution effect, as occurs for the glucose-H2 position, or because of a sensitivity to 2H at a key step in lactic acid biosynthesis. The latter will lead to positive discrimination against 2H (i.e. KIE >1). KIEs for l-lactate dehydrogenase have been described both for the binding (20LaReau R. Wan W. Anderson V. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 3619-3624Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar) and the catalytic (21Thomson J. Darling J. Bordner L. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1964; 85: 177-185PubMed Google Scholar) steps of pyruvate reduction. Hence, selectivity against 2H is probable, leading to the observed diminished transfer. In contrast, for the CH3 no apparent selectivity against 2H has occurred. Two of the three hydrogens in this position are derived directly from the 6,6′-Hs of glucose without any reaction. Alternatively, these positions are derived from the H1 position without reaction and the H2 position with intramolecular transfer by glucose-6-phosphate isomerase (EC5.3.1.9). It would appear that this enzyme shows little sensitivity to 2H. The third hydrogen in the CH3 is derived from water, without any apparent KIE. Ln. mesenteroides—The deuterium content of lactic acid isolated from the fermentation of glucose with Ln. mesenteroides is summarized in Table III. These data show that the transfer of deuterium from the glucose to the lactic acid is site-specific, varies with the position j of the substrate, and the affiliations do not have the same relationship as obtained with Lc. lactis. From the data in Table III, the Equations 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15 are obtained. (D/H)CH3=0.25(D/H)m+78.9(Eq. 11) (D/H)CH=0.36(D/H)m+88.8(Eq. 12) (D/H)CH3=0.07(D/H)1+103.0(Eq. 13) (D/H)CH3=0.32(D/H)6,6′+68.7(Eq. 14) (D/H)CH=0.18(D/H)1+111.0(Eq. 15) (D/H)CH=0.38(D/H)3+86.9(Eq. 16) Isotope transfer coefficients for both positions with (D/H)2 and (D/H)4, for (D/H)CH3 with (D/H)3, and for (D/H)CH with (D/H)6,6′ are all non-significant. From Equations 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, the Cf values of each hydrogen to the CH3 or CH(OH) of d-lactic acid produced by Ln. mesenteroides can be estimated. Because during RPP metabolism, in contrast to glycolysis, nRH totally proteated glucose molecules are converted to only nRH molecules of lactic acid, Glucose(H)nRH→1lactic acid(H)+ 1 nRHacetyl−P+1CO2Reaction II then nRD site-j monodeuterated glucose molecules are converted to CfnRD site-i monodeuterated lactic acid molecules. Values calculated for Cf are given in Table II. Major differences and some similarities are observed when comparing these transfer coefficients to those obtained with Lc. lactis. According to the fermentation pathway in Ln. mesenteroides, the C5-C6 portion of glucose follows an affiliation pathway that should differ little from that of glycolysis, because their metabolism takes place post-G3P formation (Fig. 3). This is confirmed by the data for the H6,6′, with a Cf = 0.95, indicating that these hydrogens remain attached to the C6 throughout. Although the glucose C4 might also be seen to follow the same pathway, the data show no affiliation between H4 and d-lactic acid (Tables II, III), suggesting that the glucose-H4 is not transferred to NAD+ during the action of G3P dehydrogenase (EC1.2.1.12). This is explained by the isomerization of ribulose-5-P to xylulose-5-P by the reversible enzyme, ribulose-5-P 3-epimerase (EC5.1.3.1) (Fig. 3, step 4). It has been shown by isotopic labeling that the inversion of configuration at the 3 position of the pentose involves a two-base mechanism, because the hydrogen at position 3 of the product, xylulose-5-P, is derived from water (22McDonough M.W. Wood W.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1961; 236: 1220-1224Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Davis L. Lee N. Glaser L. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 5862-5866Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The C1-C2-C3 moiety of glucose is metabolized quite differently by the two pathways. In the RPP route, H1 and H3 are both transferred to NAD(P)+, whereas the H2 remains attached to the C2 and, consequently, does not participate in lactic acid formation. This is confirmed because aCH3,2 and aCH,2 are both zero. Rather, H2 should be recovered in the metabolites derived from acetyl-P, ethanol, and acetate (Figs. 1 and 3). Theoretically, the reduction of pyruvate to lactate could introduce hydrogen from H1 and H3 of glucose into the CH(OH). This is confirmed because both aCH,1 and aCH,3 are high, showing Cf values somewhat higher than that for aCH,4 in Lc. lactis (Table II) or for aCH,4 in ethanol and glycerol biosynthesis (7Pionnier S. Robins R. Zhang B.-L. J. Agric. Food. Chem. 2003; 51: 2076-2082Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). Because d-lactate dehydrogenase (EC1.1.1.28), at least from Lactobacillus plantarum (10Dennis D. Kaplan N.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1960; 235: 810-818Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), is inactive with NADPH, all reoxidation of any NADPH produced by G6P 1-dehydrogenase (EC1.1.1.49) and 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase (EC3.1.1.31) requires conversion to NADH by transhydrogenase activity. Thus, the 2-fold difference between aCH,1 (0.18) and aCH,3 (0.38) could be explained by different affinities of these two dehydrogenases for NAD+ and NADP+. It has been demonstrated that, for the enzymes of Ln. mesenteroides, the cofactor selectivity of G6P dehydrogenase for NAD+/NADP+ = 0.67, whereas the selectivity of 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is 25-fold in favor of NAD+ (24DeMoss R. Methods Enzymol. 1955; 1: 328-334Crossref Scopus (81) Google Scholar). Hence, the differences in H1-Cf and H3-Cf can readily be explained by differential loss of 2H to the medium during transhydrogenation. The observed significant Cf for glucose-H1 and the CH3 of lactate is, in contrast, intriguing. For the RPP pathway, no such affiliation should occur, suggesting that this could arise because of low activity of another metabolic route. One possibility is that limited glycolysis occurs at a level sufficient to observe the small a1,CH3 but insufficient to observe the even smaller a2,CH3 that should be associated with it. Because a3,CH3 is zero, it is improbable that the H1 transfer is through NAD(P)H. The manipulation of flux to enhance or diminish the accumulation of particular target products is a major goal of biotechnology when applied to microbial fermentations. Lactic acid bacteria are no exception (25Hoefnagel M. Starrenburg M. Martens D. Hugenholtz J. Kleerebezem M. Van Swam I. Bongers R. Westerhoff H. Snoep J. Microbiology. 2002; 148: 1003-1013Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar), but it is evident that the exact manipulation required to optimize the desired effect is not always easily defined. In part, this is because of the difficulty of predicting the influence of metabolic regulation. Metabolic flux control studies have made some progress toward fully describing how glucose metabolism in Lc. lactis is controlled (26Koebmann B. Andersen H. Solem C. Jensen P. Antonie Leeuwenhoek. 2002; 82: 237-248Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 27Neves A. Ventura R. Mansour N. Shearman C. Gasson M. Maycock C. Ramos A. Santos H. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 28088-28098Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). In particular, it is apparent that down-regulation of one route, such as lactate dehydrogenation for NAD+ regeneration, is likely to elicit several alternative metabolic strategies (4Monnet C. Aymes F. Corrieu G. Appl. Environ. Microbiol. 2000; 66: 5518-5520Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar), not all of which are desirable. Furthermore, different routes can lead to the same end product; for example, acetate and lactate can both be produced by the glycolytic and RPP pathways (Fig. 1). Quantifying the relative contribution of each route under conditions in which both alternatives are active can be problematic.

Chemoattractant-stimulated pseudopod growth in human neutrophils was used as a model system to study the rate-limiting mechanism of cytoskeleton rearrangement induced by activated G-protein-coupled receptors. Cells were activated with N-formyl-Met-Leu-Phe, and the temperature dependence of the rate of pseudopod extension was measured in the presence of pharmacological inhibitors with known mechanisms of action. Three groups of inhibitors were used: (i) inhibitors sequestering substrates involved in F-actin polymerization (latrunculin A for G-actin and cytochalasin D for actin filament-free barbed ends) or sequestering secondary messengers (PIP-binding peptide for phosphoinositide lipids); (ii) competitively binding inhibitors (Akt-inhibitor for Akt/protein kinase B); and (iii) inhibitors that reduce enzyme activity (wortmannin for phosphoinositide 3-kinase and chelerythrine for protein kinase C). The experimental data are consistent with a model in which the relative involvement of a given pathway of F-actin polymerization to the measured rate of pseudopod extension is limited by a slowest (bottleneck) reaction in the cascade of reactions involved in the overall signaling pathway. The approach we developed was used to demonstrate that chemoattractant-induced pseudopod growth and mechanically stimulated cytoskeleton rearrangement are controlled by distinct pathways of F-actin polymerization. The experimental data are consistent with a model in which the relative involvement of a given pathway of F-actin polymerization to the measured rate of pseudopod extension is limited by a slowest (bottleneck) reaction in the cascade of reactions involved in the overall signaling pathway.
