IntroductionCirculating neutrophils are activated by a variety of stimuli that induce chemotaxis, chemokinesis, phagocytosis, release of proteases, and production of superoxide anions (1Snyderman R. Uhing R.J. Gallin J.I. Goldstein I.M. Snyderman R. Inflammation: Basic Principles and Clinical Correlates. Raven Press, New York, NY1992: 421-439Google Scholar, 2Stossel T.P. Gallin J.I. Goldstein I.M. Snyderman R. Inflammation: Basic Principles and Clinical Correlates. Raven Press, New York, NY1992: 459-475Google Scholar). G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) 1The abbreviations used are: GPCR, G-protein coupled receptor; PI3K, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinases; PK, protein kinase; fMLP, formylmethionylleucylphenylalanine; BAPTA-AM, 1,2-bis(2-aminophenoxy)ethane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid; PtdIns(3,4)P2, phosphatidylinositol 3,4-bisphosphate; PtdIns(3,4,5)P3, phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate; PH, pleckstrin homology; GM-CSF; granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor. play a major role in the regulation of these cellular functions by recognizing chemoattractants released by invading bacteria and cytokines released by tissue cells and various cells of the immune system (1Snyderman R. Uhing R.J. Gallin J.I. Goldstein I.M. Snyderman R. Inflammation: Basic Principles and Clinical Correlates. Raven Press, New York, NY1992: 421-439Google Scholar, 3Luster A.D. New Engl. J. Med. 1998; 338: 436-445Google Scholar). The signaling pathways initiated by ligated GPCRs are divided into two major groups: one group controls cellular chemotaxis and is dependent upon kinase activity of the class IA phosphatidylinositol 3-kinases (PI3K) (4Li Z. Jiang H. Xie W. Zhang Z. Smrcka A.V. Wu D. Science. 2000; 287: 1046-1049Google Scholar), whereas the other controls the release of proteases and production of superoxide anions (5Haribabu B. Zhelev D.V. Pridgen B.C. Richardson R.M. Ali H. Snyderman R. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 37087-37092Google Scholar) and is dependent upon the activity of phospholipase Cβ2 (4Li Z. Jiang H. Xie W. Zhang Z. Smrcka A.V. Wu D. Science. 2000; 287: 1046-1049Google Scholar). PI3Ks and their products play key roles in the signaling of chemotaxis (6Weiner O.D. Servant G. Welch M.D. Mitchison T.J. Sedat J.W. Bourne H.B. Nat. Cell Biol. 1999; 1: 75-81Google Scholar, 7Wang F. Herzmark P. Weiner O.D. Srinivasan S. Servant G. Bourne H.R. Nat. Cell Biol. 2002; 4: 513-518Google Scholar); however, there are alternative pathways of chemotaxis that do not require PI3K activation (8Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 101: 1181-1184Google Scholar, 9Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 102: 2251-2258Google Scholar, 10Li Z. Hannigan M. Mo Z. Liu B. Lu W. Wu Y. Smrcka A.V. Wu G. Li L. Liu M. Huang C.-K. Wu D. Cell. 2003; 114: 215-227Google Scholar, 11Welch H.C.E. Coadwell W.J. Ellson C.D. Ferguson G.J. Andrews S.R. Erjument-Bromage H. Tempst P. Hawkins P.T. Stephens L.R. Cell. 2002; 108: 809-821Google Scholar). Both PI3K-dependent and -independent signaling of chemotaxis are dependent upon tyrosine kinase activation, which modulates the GPCR-mediated activation by means of receptor tyrosine kinases (9Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 102: 2251-2258Google Scholar), intracellular tyrosine kinases (12Xu J. Wang F. Keymeulen A.V. Herzmark P. Straight A. Kelly K. Takuwa Y. Sugimoto N. Mitchison T. Bourne H.R. Cell. 2003; 114: 201-214Google Scholar), or both (13Rane M.J. Coxon P.Y. Powell D.W. Webster R. Klein J.B. Pierce W. Ping P. McLeish K.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 3517-3523Google Scholar, 14Heit B. Tavener S. Raharjo E. Kubes P. J. Cell Biol. 2002; 159: 91-102Google Scholar). The complexity of the signaling of neutrophil chemotaxis is essential for the functioning of the cells during innate immune responses, and its further elucidation will allow for better control over the immune responses in pathology and disease.It is widely accepted that chemotaxis is intimately related to signaling of F-actin polymerization in the lamellae region (15Pollard T.D. Blanchoin L. Mullins R.D. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struct. 2000; 29: 545-576Google Scholar, 16Katanaev V.L. Biochemistry. 2001; 66: 351-368Google Scholar, 17Zhelev D.V. Alteraifi A. Annals Biomed. Eng. 2002; 30: 356-370Google Scholar) and generation of a protrusive force by newly formed cytoskeleton structures (18Herant M. Marganski W.A. Dembo M. Biophys. J. 2003; 84: 3389-3413Google Scholar, 19Cameron L.A. Svitkina T.M. Vignjevic D. Theriot J.A. Borisy G.G. Curr. Biol. 2001; 11: 130-135Google Scholar, 20Mogilner A. Oster G. Biophys. J. 1996; 71: 3030-3045Google Scholar, 21Mogilner A. Oster G. Biophys. J. 2003; 84: 1591-1605Google Scholar). Although the origin of the protrusive force is still being debated (18Herant M. Marganski W.A. Dembo M. Biophys. J. 2003; 84: 3389-3413Google Scholar, 22Upadhyaya A. Oudenaarden A.V. Curr. Biol. 2003; 13: R734-R744Google Scholar), it is recognized that signaling of F-actin dynamics plays a critical role in chemotaxis (23Borisy G.G. Svitkina T.M. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2000; 12: 104-112Google Scholar). The dynamics of a rearranging cytoskeleton is dependent upon the spatial and temporal localization of a variety of signaling molecules, some of which localize to the leading lamellae and others to the uropod (24Caroni P. EMBO J. 2001; 20: 4332-4336Google Scholar, 25Laux T. Fukami K. Thelen M. Golub T. Frey D. Caroni P. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 149: 1455-1472Google Scholar, 26Pierini L.M. Eddy R.J. Fuortes M. Seveau S. Casulo C. Maxfield F.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 10831-10841Google Scholar). The role of spatial and temporal signaling in chemotaxis is not yet completely understood; however, the molecules that localize to the leading lamella seem to control actin polymerization to form a highly branched cytoskeleton network (the “dendritic” model for F-actin polymerization) (15Pollard T.D. Blanchoin L. Mullins R.D. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struct. 2000; 29: 545-576Google Scholar, 23Borisy G.G. Svitkina T.M. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2000; 12: 104-112Google Scholar). The involvement of localized molecules in the signaling of F-actin polymerization induces the formation of almost cylindrical pseudopods when chemoattractant is delivered to a small surface region of a non-adherent cell with micropipets (27Zhelev D.V. Alteraifi A.M. Hochmuth R.M. Cell Motil. Cytoskeleton. 1996; 35: 331-344Google Scholar). The addition of new filaments to the F-actin network at the tip of the pseudopod results in the extension of pseudopod length without a significant change in pseudopod thickness. Thus, the measurement of the rate of pseudopod extension in different experimental conditions is expected to provide valuable information for the dynamics of chemoattractant-induced F-actin polymerization (8Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 101: 1181-1184Google Scholar, 9Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 102: 2251-2258Google Scholar, 27Zhelev D.V. Alteraifi A.M. Hochmuth R.M. Cell Motil. Cytoskeleton. 1996; 35: 331-344Google Scholar).The key role of cellular kinases, such as the class IA PI3Ks (4Li Z. Jiang H. Xie W. Zhang Z. Smrcka A.V. Wu D. Science. 2000; 287: 1046-1049Google Scholar), Akt/PKB, or PKC (28Laudanna C. Mochly-Rosen D. Liron T. Constantin G. Butcher E.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30306-30315Google Scholar), in chemotaxis suggests that the polymerization of F-actin induced with chemoattractant may be limited by the rates of involved enzymatic reactions. Here, we explore this possibility by characterizing the temperature dependence of the rate of pseudopod extension in the presence of pharmacological inhibitors that either affect key components of the reaction of F-actin polymerization or modulate PI3K activity and downstream PI3K-dependent signaling events.The overall rate of enzymatic chain reactions is often determined by a rate-limiting or bottleneck reaction, which simplifies the analysis of reaction kinetics (29Meyer E.L. Gahring L.C. Rogers S.W. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 10869-10875Google Scholar, 30Truhlar D.G. Kohen A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 848-851Google Scholar). In many cases, the overall reaction rate has a simple temperature dependence that is described by the van Hoff-Arrhenius (or Arrhenius) relationship (30Truhlar D.G. Kohen A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 848-851Google Scholar), k=Ae−EaRT(Eq. 1) where k is the rate of the enzymatic process, A is pre-exponential factor, Ea is barrier energy, R is the gas constant, and T is temperature.Many of the individual processes involved in cytoskeleton rearrangement have been described in terms of Arrhenius relations (30Truhlar D.G. Kohen A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 848-851Google Scholar, 31Alteraifi A.M. Zhelev D.V. J. Cell Sci. 1997; 110: 1967-1977Google Scholar, 32Xu C. Watras J. Loew L.M. J. Cell Biol. 2003; 161: 779-791Google Scholar, 33Southwick F. Young C. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 110: 1965-1973Google Scholar, 34Cassimeris L. Safer D. Nachmias V. Zigmond S. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 119: 1261-1270Google Scholar, 35Wolven A.K. Belmont L.D. Mahoney N.M. Almo S.C. Drubin D.G. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 150: 895-904Google Scholar, 36Perelroizen I. Didry D. Christensen H. Chua N.-H. Carlier M.-F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 12302-12309Google Scholar), which suggest the possibility for a simple temperature dependence of the overall process of pseudopod extension. Here we use a phenomenological approach, in which the temperature dependencies of two recently identified pathways of pseudopod extension, the PI3K-dependent and PI3K-independent pathways (8Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 101: 1181-1184Google Scholar, 9Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 102: 2251-2258Google Scholar), are assumed to obey the Arrhenius law, and the PI3K-independent pathway is assumed to have a negligible contribution to the overall process of F-actin polymerization. These conditions are met for pseudopod extension stimulated with fMLP, where 80% of the rate of pseudopod extension at 37 °C is PI3K-dependent (8Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 101: 1181-1184Google Scholar).EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESCell Preparation—Human neutrophils were freshly isolated as described elsewhere (9Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 102: 2251-2258Google Scholar). Briefly, whole blood was obtained by venipuncture from consenting, healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29 ± 9.5 years) into Vacutainers anticoagulated with K2EDTA. Neutrophils were isolated by a one-step density gradient (Polymorphoprep, Nycomed, Oslo, Norway) centrifugation at 500 × g for 35 min at 23 °C. The neutrophil fraction was collected and washed once with Ca2+/Mg2+-containing Hanks' balanced salt solution (Sigma). The cells were resuspended in an autologous plasma/Hanks' balanced salt solution (1:3, v/v) and added to the manipulation chamber filled with the same solution. Microscopic evaluation of isolated cells indicated that 95% of the cells were neutrophils and >98% viable, as measured by trypan blue dye exclusion. Approval for these studies was obtained from the Institutional Review Board at Duke University.Incubation with Inhibitors—The used inhibitors were initially diluted in either ethanol or dimethyl sulfoxide (Me2SO) at a maximum final concentration of 0.8% or 0.2% respectively. The presence of ethanol or Me2SO had no measurable effect on the rates of pseudopod extension (data not shown). Cells were incubated with or without inhibitors at room temperature (23 °C) using the following concentrations and times of incubation: latrunculin A (1 nm for 30 min; Biomol Research Laboratories, Plymouth Meeting, PA), cytochalasin D (1 μm for 45 min; Biomol Research Laboratories), PIP-binding peptide (Ac-Lys(Dansyl)-Gly-Gly-Gly-Gln-Arg-Leu-Phe-Gln-Val-Lys-Gly-Arg-Arg; 10 μm for 30 min), 2The peptide was synthesized in the University of North Carolina Microprotein Sequencing and Peptide Synthesis Facility, Chapel Hill, NC. Its molecular weight and purity were confirmed with mass spectrometry. 1L-6-hydroxymethyl-chiro-inositol 2-(R)-2-O-methyl-3-O-octadecylcarbonate (Akt-inhibitor; 10 μm for 60 min; Calbiochem, San Diego, CA), wortmannin (100–1000 nm for 15 min; Sigma), chelerythrine chloride (2.5 μm for 30 min; Biomol Research Laboratories), and 1,2-bis(2-aminophenoxy)ethane-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid (BAPTA-AM; 75 μm for 45 min; Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR).Micromanipulation—Micromanipulation was performed in a temperature-controlled 2-mm thick chamber, which allowed for cell micromanipulation from two axially inserted micropipets. Micropipets were made from capillary glass tubing (A-M Systems Inc., Everett, WA) pulled with a vertical pipette puller (David Kopf Instruments Model 730, Tujunga, CA). The tip of the pipettes were cut using a microforge and connected to a manometer system, which allowed for precise delivery of chemoattractant by controlling the pipette-chamber pressure difference. The temperature of the experimental chamber was varied by a flow of thermostated water at the top of the chamber. The temperature in the viewing area was measured with a thermocouple.In the experiments of pseudopod extension, a single, passive neutrophil with a smooth membrane surface and uniform optical density was chosen. The cell was held in a supporting pipette with a 5-μm internal diameter. Another pipette with an internal diameter of 1 μm was filled with a solution of N-formyl-Met-Leu-Phe (Sigma) and positioned 1 μm from the cell surface. The chemoattractant solution was blown over the cell, which initiated the extension of a single pseudopod (27Zhelev D.V. Alteraifi A.M. Hochmuth R.M. Cell Motil. Cytoskeleton. 1996; 35: 331-344Google Scholar). In the experiments of F-actin polymerization along membrane tethers, tethers were pulled from single, passive neutrophils using latex beads with conjugated CD18 mAb (BD Biosciences) (31Alteraifi A.M. Zhelev D.V. J. Cell Sci. 1997; 110: 1967-1977Google Scholar). Pseudopod extension or advancement of a pseudopod-like structure along tethers was observed by using an inverted Nikon microscope equipped with a 60× oil-immersion objective. The microscope images were recorded using a charge-coupled device camera (Cohu, San Diego, CA). A real-time counter and the chamber temperature were multiplexed onto the recorded images using a multiplexer (Vista Electronics, La Mesa, CA). The recorded images were analyzed with Metamorph Imaging software (Universal Imaging Corp., Downingtown, PA), and the rate of pseudopod extension was calculated from the measured pseudopod lengths and time lapses. Approximately 90% of the neutrophils tested produced pseudopods. The non-responding fraction of cells is not reported in the averages of the rates of pseudopod extension.RESULTSPseudopod Extension Induced by Chemoattractant Delivered from a Micropipet—The micropipet assay for pseudopod extension from non-adherent cells used a steep chemoattractant gradient to stimulate F-actin polymerization at a local region of the cell and to induce a single pseudopod growth. 3Zhelev, D. V., Alteraifi, A. M., and Chodniewicz, D. (2004) Biophys. J., in press. This results in several distinct characteristics of formation of these pseudopods including: (i) the existence of a time of delay between the beginning of chemoattractant delivery and initial pseudopod growth (Fig. 1); (ii) the stimulation of shape change only in the pseudopod region, which was observed as an increase in pseudopod length (Fig. 1); (iii) the continuous increase of pseudopod length until a maximum length was reached, after which the growth of the pseudopod stopped abruptly and its length started to decrease; (iv) the repetitive pseudopod extension and retraction until the delivery of chemoattractant was continued. We have shown that the extension and the retraction of the pseudopod in the presence of chemoattractant is actively regulated and is dependent upon the activity of the small GTPase RhoA and its downstream effector kinase ROCK. 3Zhelev, D. V., Alteraifi, A. M., and Chodniewicz, D. (2004) Biophys. J., in press. These observations show that the overall process of pseudopod growth over an extended period of time is an actively regulated multiphase process. Therefore, we focused our measurements on the initial pseudopod extension, which was linear in time (Fig. 1) and, therefore, was most probably dependent upon a single rate-limiting process. The linear increase of the pseudopod growth was independent of the treatment with pharmacological inhibitors (Fig. 1), which showed that the rate of pseudopod extension induced with the micropipet assay provides information for the dynamics of cytoskeleton rearrangement in the presence of inhibitors. In the following sections, we examine the dependence of the rate of pseudopod extension upon temperature in the presence of different inhibitors.Changing Substrate ConcentrationSequestering G-actin with Latrunculin A and Capping F-actin Filaments with Cytochalasin D—Actin in human neutrophils is subject to continuous turnover, where actin monomers are shuttled between G-actin and F-actin. G-actin in the neutrophil is sequestered by either profilin (33Southwick F. Young C. J. Cell Biol. 1990; 110: 1965-1973Google Scholar) or thymosin-β4 (34Cassimeris L. Safer D. Nachmias V. Zigmond S. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 119: 1261-1270Google Scholar). Profilin, a nucleotide exchange factor (35Wolven A.K. Belmont L.D. Mahoney N.M. Almo S.C. Drubin D.G. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 150: 895-904Google Scholar, 36Perelroizen I. Didry D. Christensen H. Chua N.-H. Carlier M.-F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 12302-12309Google Scholar), recovers the ADP-bound actin after its release during cofilin-assisted severing of F-actin filaments (37Maciver S.K. Pope B.J. Whytock S. Weeds A.G. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 256: 388-397Google Scholar). Profilin mediates the formation of ATP-actin, which is then added to free F-actin barbed ends (38Carlier M.-F. Laurent V. Santolini J. Melki R. Didry D. Xia G.-X. Hong Y. Chua N.-H. Pantaloni D. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 136: 1307-1322Google Scholar). The overall rate of F-actin polymerization is dependent upon both the availability of actin for polymerization and the availability of free filament ends where the ATP-actin is polymerized (15Pollard T.D. Blanchoin L. Mullins R.D. Annu. Rev. Biophys. Biomol. Struct. 2000; 29: 545-576Google Scholar).Latrunculin A binds actin with high affinity, thereby inhibiting the binding of thymosin-β4 (39Yarmola E.G. Somasundaram T. Boring T.A. Spector I. Bubb M.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 28120-28127Google Scholar). The identification of the binding site of latrunculin A to actin revealed that it is also near the binding site for nucleotide (40Morton W.M. Ayscough K.R. McLaughlin P.J. Nat. Cell. Bio. 2000; 2: 376-378Google Scholar). Therefore, latrunculin A blocks nucleotide binding to actin while simultaneously blocking profilin-mediated nucleotide exchange (41Ayscough K.R. Stryker J. Pokala N. Sanders M. Crews P. Drubin D.G. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 137: 399-416Google Scholar). The ability of latrunculin A to prevent both sequestering of actin by thymosin-β4 and binding of nucleotide to actin makes it a good sequestering agent for G-actin. The incubation of neutrophils with 10 nm latrunculin A decreased the rate of pseudopod extension without significantly affecting the apparent barrier energy for pseudopod formation (Fig. 2A). Cytochalasin D, which blocks free barbed ends of F-actin (42Cooper J. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 105: 1473-1478Google Scholar), was also expected to decrease the overall rate of F-actin polymerization. Similar to latrunculin A, the incubation of the cells with 1 μm cytochalasin D decreased the rate of pseudopod extension without significantly affecting the barrier energy of pseudopod extension (Fig. 2A).Fig. 2Effect of changing substrate concentration on the rate of pseudopod extension. A, sequestering of cellular G-actin with 10 nm latrunculin A (•), blocking of free actin filament ends with 1 μm cytochalasin D (▪), or sequestering PtdIns lipids with 10 μm PIP-binding peptide (▴) decreased the rate of pseudopod extension without significantly affecting the slope of the Arrhenius plot of the experimental data. B, the rate of pseudopod extension increased with increasing chemoattractant concentration until a concentration of saturation was reached. The increase of the rate of pseudopod extension occurred without changes of the slopes of the Arrhenius plots.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT)Sequestering Phosphatidylinositide Lipids with PIP-binding Peptide—Phosphatidylinositol 3,4-bisphosphate (PtdIns(3,4)P2) and phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate (PtdIns(3,4,5)P3) are two main downstream messengers of PI3K-dependent signaling (7Wang F. Herzmark P. Weiner O.D. Srinivasan S. Servant G. Bourne H.R. Nat. Cell Biol. 2002; 4: 513-518Google Scholar, 43Bokoch G.M. Blood. 1995; 86: 1649-1660Google Scholar). PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 is synthesized from PtdIns(4,5)P2 (44Fruman D.A. Meyers R.E. Cantley L.C. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 481-507Google Scholar) and is a pivotal downstream regulator of cellular chemotaxis (45Weiner O.D. Neilsen P.O. Prestwich G.D. Kirschner M.W. Cantley L.C. Bourne H.R. Nat. Cell. Bio. 2002; 4: 509-513Google Scholar). The cell-permeable peptide Ac-Gln-Arg-Leu-Phe-Gln-Val-Lys-Gly-Arg-Arg (PIP-binding peptide), synthesized after the binding domain for PtdIns(4,5)P2 of gelsolin (46Xian W. Vegners R. Janmey P. Braunlin W. Biophys. J. 1995; 69: 2695-2702Google Scholar), has been used successfully to inhibit F-actin polymerization and arrest cell migration (47Cunningham C.C. Vegners R. Bucki R. Funaki M. Korde N. Hartwig J.H. Stossel T.P. Janmey P.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 43390-43399Google Scholar). The specificity of this peptide for binding different phosphatidylinositides has not been characterized; however, it sequesters PtdIns(4,5)P2 with high efficiency (47Cunningham C.C. Vegners R. Bucki R. Funaki M. Korde N. Hartwig J.H. Stossel T.P. Janmey P.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 43390-43399Google Scholar). The incubation of neutrophils with 10 μm PIP-binding peptide decreased the rate of pseudopod extension at 37 °C more than two times compared with control, without affecting the slopes of the Arrhenius plots, which are a measure of the apparent barrier energy for pseudopod extension (Fig. 2A).Effect of Chemoattractant Concentration—We have shown that the rate of pseudopod extension is dependent upon chemoattractant concentration at room temperature and at 37 °C (9Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 102: 2251-2258Google Scholar, 31Alteraifi A.M. Zhelev D.V. J. Cell Sci. 1997; 110: 1967-1977Google Scholar). The increase of chemoattractant concentration increases the number of ligand-bound GPCRs and was expected to increase the apparent concentration of downstream substrates synthesized after receptor activation. The measurement of the rate of pseudopod extension for increasing concentrations of chemoattractant showed that the rate of pseudopod extension increased without a change in the barrier energy for pseudopod extension (Fig. 2B).Reducing the Apparent Concentration of Activated Enzyme with Competitively Binding Substrates—Downstream effectors of PI3K activation include pleckstrin homology (PH) domain proteins, which bind 3′-phosphorylated lipids. Akt/protein kinase B (Akt/PKB) is a major downstream regulator of PI3K-dependent chemotaxis (7Wang F. Herzmark P. Weiner O.D. Srinivasan S. Servant G. Bourne H.R. Nat. Cell Biol. 2002; 4: 513-518Google Scholar, 8Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 101: 1181-1184Google Scholar, 48Servant G. Weiner O.D. Herzmark P. Balla T. Sedat J.W. Bourne H.R. Science. 2000; 287: 1037-1040Google Scholar, 49Burgering B.M. Coffer P.J. Nature. 1995; 376: 599-602Google Scholar). Akt/PKB binds both PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 and PtdIns(3,4)P2, resulting in its recruitment to the plasma membrane and its phosphorylation at specific residues, Thr308 and Ser473 (50Coffer P.J. Jin J. Woodgett J.R. Biochem. J. 1998; 335: 1-13Google Scholar). Phosphorylation at Ser473 is an indicator of Akt/PKB activation, and phosphorylation of this amino acid is a prerequisite for Akt/PKB activity (51Hill M.M. Feng J. Hemmings B.A. Curr. Biol. 2002; 12: 1251-1255Google Scholar). We used the phosphatidylinositol ether analog 1L-6-hydroxymethylchiro-inositol 2-(R)-2-O-methyl-3-O-octadecylcarbonate (Akt-inhibitor) to competitively bind and reduce the total available Akt/PKB for activation by 3′-phosphorylated lipids (52Hu Y. Qiao L. Wang S. Rong S. Meuillet E.J. Berggren M. Gakeros A. Powis G. Kozikowski A.P. J. Med. Chem. 2000; 43: 3045-3051Google Scholar). The specificity of the Akt-inhibitor has not been tested thoroughly; however, it has been shown that in the human myelocytic leukemic cell line, HL-60, 40 μm Akt-inhibitor blocked Ser473-Akt phosphorylation without affecting the phosphorylation and activity of PKC-ζ and had a minimum effect upon the production of PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 (53Martelli A.M. Tazzari P.L. Tabelini G. Bortul R. Billi A.M. Manzoli L. Ruggeri A. Conte R. Cocco L. Leukemia. 2003; 17: 1794-1805Google Scholar). PKC together with Akt/PKB have been identified as downstream effectors of PI3K activity in the signaling of pseudopod extension (8Chodniewicz D. Zhelev D.V. Blood. 2003; 101: 1181-1184Google Scholar) and chemotaxis (28Laudanna C. Mochly-Rosen D. Liron T. Constantin G. Butcher E.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 30306-30315Google Scholar). Therefore, at least for the signaling of pseudopod extension, the effect of Akt-inhibitor is considered to be blocking Akt/PKB activation. We tested the effect of Akt-inhibitor on the rate of pseudopod extension, Akt/PKB phosphorylation, and on PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 production (see supplemental material). The effect of Akt-inhibitor on the rate of pseudopod extension was similar to the effect of wortmannin. 40 μm Akt-inhibitor was sufficient to block PI3K-dependent pseudopod extension and almost completely block Ser473-Akt phosphorylation, while having only a minor effect upon PtdIns(3,4,5)P3 production (see supplemental material). These findings suggest that the Akt-inhibitor has a similar effect upon neutrophil activation as upon the activation of HL-60 cells. The incubation of neutrophils with 10 μm Akt-inhibitor decreased the rate of pseudopod extension, without affecting the barrier energy for pseudopod growth (Fig. 3).Fig. 3Effect of blocking enzyme activation on the rate of pseudopod extension. The binding of PtdIns lipids to Akt/PKB and the activation of the enzyme were blocked with the competitively binding inhibitor 1L-6-hydroxymethyl-chiro-inositol 2-(R)-2-O-methyl-3-O-octadecylcarbonate (Akt-inhibitor). The blocking of enzymatic activity decreased the rate of pseudopod extension without affecting the slope of the Arrhenius plots.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT)Reducing Enzyme ActivityReducing PI3K Activity with Wortm

We have investigated peptides corresponding to the complete transmembrane region of both proto-oncogenic (Val664) and mutant (Glu664) forms of the receptor Neu in detergent micelles by NMR and CD spectroscopy. Both forms of the peptide appear to adopt similar levels of helicity and dimeric interactions based on the analysis of CD spectra and nuclear Overhauser effect connectivity profiles. There are considerable differences in the chemical shifts of amide and, to a lesser extent, CHα resonances between the two forms of the peptides, and these differences are most pronounced in residues upstream of the mutation site and close to the N terminus of the transmembrane domain. Similarly, there are substantial differences in the amide hydrogen-deuterium exchange rates for residues close to and upstream of the mutation site; amide protons in this region of the protooncogenic peptide are much more resistant to exchange than those in the mutant form. In both molecules, residues downstream of the mutation site exhibit slow exchange. We therefore demonstrate that, although transmembrane Neu peptides exhibit similar levels of secondary structure when dispersed in detergent, there are detectable differences in their adopted micellar states that may provide insight into the dimer-promoting ability of the polar transforming mutation. We have investigated peptides corresponding to the complete transmembrane region of both proto-oncogenic (Val664) and mutant (Glu664) forms of the receptor Neu in detergent micelles by NMR and CD spectroscopy. Both forms of the peptide appear to adopt similar levels of helicity and dimeric interactions based on the analysis of CD spectra and nuclear Overhauser effect connectivity profiles. There are considerable differences in the chemical shifts of amide and, to a lesser extent, CHα resonances between the two forms of the peptides, and these differences are most pronounced in residues upstream of the mutation site and close to the N terminus of the transmembrane domain. Similarly, there are substantial differences in the amide hydrogen-deuterium exchange rates for residues close to and upstream of the mutation site; amide protons in this region of the protooncogenic peptide are much more resistant to exchange than those in the mutant form. In both molecules, residues downstream of the mutation site exhibit slow exchange. We therefore demonstrate that, although transmembrane Neu peptides exhibit similar levels of secondary structure when dispersed in detergent, there are detectable differences in their adopted micellar states that may provide insight into the dimer-promoting ability of the polar transforming mutation. The catalytic activation of members of the receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) 1The abbreviations used are: RTK, receptor tyrosine kinase; TM, transmembrane; TFE, trifluoroethanol; DPC, dodecylphosphocholine; NOESY, nuclear Overhauser effect spectroscopy; TOCSY, total correlation spectroscopy; HSQC, heteronuclear single quantum coherence; CSD, chemical shift deviation from random coil value. family is generally initiated by ligand binding to the extracellular domain of a monovalent receptor that promotes dimerization, a process mediated by residues in both the extracellular and transmembrane (TM) domains. Receptor dimerization enables the trans-phosphorylation of the intracellular domain of the partner receptor and the recruitment of signaling proteins, leading to the appropriate downstream cellular response. In Neu, the rat homologue of ErbB2 (a member of the epidermal growth factor receptor subfamily), a single oncogenic mutation (Val664 → Glu) within the TM domain enhances receptor dimerization, leading to constitutive activation (1Bargmann C.I. Hung M.C. Weinberg R.A. Cell. 1986; 45: 649-657Google Scholar, 2Bargmann C.I. Weinberg R.A. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 2043-2052Google Scholar, 3Weiner D.B. Liu J. Cohen J.A. Williams W.V. Greene M.I. Nature. 1989; 339: 230-231Google Scholar). Substitution of the mutant TM domain from Neu into other RTKs increases catalytic activity and promotes cellular transformation (4Cheatham B. Shoelson S.E. Yamada K. Goncalves E. Kahn C.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 7336-7340Google Scholar, 5Petti L.M. Irusta P.M. DiMaio D. Oncogene. 1998; 16: 843-851Google Scholar, 6Wides R.J. Zak N.B. Shilo B.Z. Eur. J. Biochem. 1990; 189: 637-645Google Scholar), demonstrating that there is a common role played by this segment in the activation process. The TM domain of Neu, along with its associated transforming mutation, has become a useful paradigm with which to clarify the role played by the single helical domain in the activation of RTKs. Recent studies have demonstrated that the presence of polar residues within TM domains can, in principle, promote helix-helix association by providing an additional interhelical stabilizing force acting as both an H-bond donor and acceptor (7Choma C. Gratkowski H. Lear J.D. DeGrado W.F. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 161-166Google Scholar, 8Zhou F.X. Cocco M.J. Russ W.P. Brunger A.T. Engelman D.M. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 154-160Google Scholar, 9Zhou F.X. Merianos H.J. Brunger A.T. Engelman D.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 2250-2255Google Scholar). The transforming mutation in the receptor Neu occurs within a five-residue dimerization motif that has been identified in the majority of RTKs (10Sternberg M.J. Gullick W.J. Protein Eng. 1990; 3: 245-248Google Scholar). The local structure, dictated by the primary sequence in the motif, is critical for proper receptor dimerization and activation; replacing residues adjacent to the transforming mutation site with glutamate does not elicit the same behavior (2Bargmann C.I. Weinberg R.A. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 2043-2052Google Scholar, 11Cao H. Bangalore L. Bormann B.J. Stern D.F. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 923-932Google Scholar). Furthermore, upon activation there appears to be important coupling between the kinase domain in the intracellular region of the receptor and the contact point of the helices within the dimer structure (12Bell C.A. Tynan J.A. Hart K.C. Meyer A.N. Robertson S.C. Donoghue D.J. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2000; 11: 3589-3599Google Scholar, 13Chen L.I. Webster M.K. Meyer A.N. Donoghue D.J. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 137: 619-631Google Scholar). Thus, the harmful transforming property of the mutation arises not only because it promotes helix-helix association but because it occurs within the context of a dimerization motif. Using peptides corresponding to the TM region of mutant Neu reconstituted in lipid bilayers, Smith and colleagues (14Smith S.O. Smith C.S. Bormann B.J. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1996; 3: 252-258Google Scholar) have characterized the dimeric structure at residues close to the mutation site. They determined that the side chain carboxyl group of Glu664 is likely protonated and is a participant in an interhelical hydrogen bond (14Smith S.O. Smith C.S. Bormann B.J. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1996; 3: 252-258Google Scholar). Solid state NMR measurements indicated that there is close association between the side chain carboxyl group of Glu664 and the α-carbon atom of Gly665 of the partner helix (15Smith S.O. Smith C. Shekar S. Peersen O. Ziliox M. Aimoto S. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 9321-9332Google Scholar). These measurements led to a proposed dimer model that was symmetric and possessed a right-handed crossing angle. The elucidation of the structure of membrane proteins is a significant challenge because of the technical difficulties associated with their study using techniques such as NMR spectroscopy and x-ray crystallography. It is for this reason that a complete structural picture of the TM domain of Neu in a lipid environment remains elusive. Several lines of evidence suggest that structural details not necessarily confined to the mutation site in the TM domain may offer insight into the process of receptor activation. Molecular dynamics studies of ErbB2/Neu TM peptides, performed in vacuo, have suggested the possibility that portions of this domain may readily adopt π-helix turns capable of reorienting residues found at the dimer interface (16Duneau J.P. Garnier N. Genest M. J. Biomol. Struct. Dyn. 1997; 15: 555-572Google Scholar, 17Sajot N. Genest M. Eur. Biophys. J. 2000; 28: 648-662Google Scholar, 18Sajot N. Genest M. J. Biomol. Struct. Dyn. 2001; 19: 15-31Google Scholar). Solvent structures of both proto-oncogenic and mutant forms of the TM domain have displayed helical distortions downstream of the mutation site (19Goetz M. Carlotti C. Bontems F. Dufourc E.J. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 6534-6540Google Scholar, 20Houliston R.S. Hodges R.S. Sharom F.J. Davis J.H. FEBS Lett. 2003; 535: 39-43Google Scholar). Therefore, dimer models constructed using canonical α-helices may be overly simplistic. Wide line 2H-NMR spectral differences downstream of the mutation site have been observed between monomeric forms of proto-oncogenic and mutant Neu/ErbB2 peptides dispersed in bilayers (21Jones D.H. Ball E.H. Sharpe S. Barber K.R. Grant C.W. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 1870-1878Google Scholar, 22Sharpe S. Barber K.R. Grant C.W. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 2341-2352Google Scholar). Also, a recent theoretical study has raised the possibility that the TM domain of the ErbB2 receptor may be capable of adopting two stable dimeric conformations that are interchangeable through a 120° rotation of the individual helices (23Fleishman S.J. Schlessinger J. Ben Tal N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2002; 99: 15937-15940Google Scholar). Finally, it is still unclear whether the dimer-promoting ability of the transforming polar mutation in this large 185-kDa receptor is solely a function of the added H-bonding capability resulting from the presence of a glutamate side chain within the TM domain or whether there are additional structural or thermodynamic consequences resulting from its presence that contribute to enhanced receptor oligomerization. As an alternative to studying membrane proteins in their natural bilayer environment, detergent micelles are routinely employed to solubilize and characterize membrane-anchored proteins. Because of their relatively small size range, protein micellar complexes are amenable to investigation using standard solution state NMR techniques. In this report, we present a structural study of both proto-oncogenic and mutant peptides corresponding to the complete TM domain of Neu dispersed in detergent micelles. We have characterized the micelle-adopted states of the peptides using CD and NMR spectroscopy, and we present the banding pattern observed upon running them on SDS-polyacrylamide gels. We demonstrate that both forms of the peptide appear to form helical structures throughout the length of the putative TM region and that they adopt similar levels of interhelical interaction within the micelle environment. However, the transforming mutation causes an appreciable difference in the amide proton exchange rates in residues close to the mutation site and near the N-terminal juxtamembrane region. Synthesis of Peptides—A hydrophobicity profile of Neu suggests that its TM domain comprises 26 amino acids. The membrane flanking regions contain a proline residue at the N terminus and several basic residues at the C terminus. 36-residue peptides incorporating the entire putative TM domain and several residues from the flanking juxtamembrane regions of both proto-oncogenic and mutant Neu were synthesized using the tBOC strategy and purified by reversed-phase chromatography. The purity of the peptides, judged to be >90%, was confirmed by mass spectrometry. The sequence of the proto-oncogenic peptide, corresponding to the position of the amino acids within the Neu receptor, is Q651RASPVTFIIATVV664GVLLFLILVVVVGILIKRRRQK686. The mutant peptide has an identical sequence, except at position 664, where valine is replaced with glutamic acid. Within our peptides, the mutation site corresponds to residue 14. Heteronuclear NMR experiments were performed with 15N incorporated at six sites within the peptide backbone of both peptides, namely Val6, Ala11, Gly15, Phe19, Leu22, and Gly27. CD Spectroscopy—Spectra were acquired on an AVIV Model 215 instrument (AVIV Associates, Lakewood, NJ), using a 1-mm path length quartz cell at 25 °C in trifluoroethanol (TFE) and in SDS and dodecylphosphocholine (DPC) micelles. The peptide concentration was ∼ 25 μm under all conditions. For samples in which peptides were dispersed in micelles, the detergent concentration was 100 mm. Helical content was estimated using either a deconvolution algorithm with the aid of the program CDNN (24Bohm G. Muhr R. Jaenicke R. Protein Eng. 1992; 5: 191-195Google Scholar) or a method based on the molar ellipticity value at 222 nm ([Θ]222) as described by Chang et al. (25Chang C.T. Wu C.S. Yang J.T. Anal. Biochem. 1978; 91: 13-31Google Scholar). NMR Spectroscopy—Approximately 3 mg (∼1.5 mm) of purified peptide was solubilized in 100 mm d38-DPC (Cambridge Isotope Laboratories) at a solution pH of 4. To make the 1H assignments in this detergent, standard two-dimensional homonuclear correlation spectra were acquired at 50 °C on a Bruker Avance spectrometer operating at 600 MHz. Proton chemical shifts were referenced to the internal standard tetramethylsilane. Nuclear Overhauser enhancement (NOESY) spectra with mixing times of 200, 250, and 300 ms were acquired using a presaturation pulse during the relaxation delay to suppress the H2O peak and a time-proportional phase increment (TPPI) for quadrature detection. We attempted to make the assignment of as many scalar coupled networks as possible with TOCSY spectra acquired using a DIPSI-2 pulse scheme (26Shaka A.J. Lee C.J. Pines A. J. Magn. Reson. 1988; 77: 274-293Google Scholar), isotropic mixing times of 30, 50, and 75 ms, solvent suppression using WATERGATE (27Piotto M. Saudek V. Sklenar V. J. Biomol. NMR. 1992; 2: 661-665Google Scholar), and an echo-antiecho phase cycle for quadrature detection. All two-dimensional homonuclear spectra were acquired with 2048 points in the direct dimension, 256–512 points in the indirect dimension, and 128–256 scans per increment. The resolution obtained from the homonuclear spectra in detergent was not sufficient to enable the assignment of all of the backbone 1H resonances in either form of the peptide. To help resolve some of the ambiguities, we synthesized these molecules with 15N labels incorporated at six positions (see above). To assign the 1H and 15N resonances at these six sites, we performed standard 1H–15N heteronuclear single quantum coherence (HSQC) spectra (28Kay L.E. Keifer P. Saarinen T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1992; 114: 10663-10665Google Scholar), 15N-filtered NOESY spectra with mixing times of 250 and 300 ms (29Otting G. Senn H. Wagner G. Wuthrich K. J. Magn. Reson. 2004; 70: 500-505Google Scholar), and 1H–15N TOCSY-HSQC spectra with a mixing time of 75 ms. Solvent suppression was achieved using a presaturation pulse for the 15N-filtered NOESY spectra and water flip-back pulses for the 1H–15N HSQC and TOCSY-HSQC spectra. Once the 1H assignments at the labeled sites were made, we reanalyzed the two-dimensional homonuclear spectra and were able to assign the majority of the backbone and CHβ resonances within the helical portions of both peptides. All NMR data were processed using software Felix97 (Biosym) on an O2 work station (Silicon Graphics, Inc.). One final procedural note should be added regarding sample preparation for NMR experiments, i.e. when solubilizing these peptides in detergent, the sample was not subjected to a vortex but was gently resuspended using a pipette. We noticed that subjecting the samples to a vortex led to the loss of NMR signal, possibly because this promoted the aggregation of the peptides. Amide Exchange Experiments—Hexa-(15N)-labeled proto-oncogenic and mutant peptides (∼1.5 mm) were dispersed in 100 mm DPC at pH 4. The peptide/micelle solution was lyophilized and redissolved in D2O. Amide exchange rates were determined from the rate of decay in successive 1H–15N HSQC spectra acquired continuously over a 24-h time period at 40 °C. Roughly 20 min elapsed between redissolution in D2O and the acquisition of the first spectrum. Each time point took ∼ 60 and ∼ 75 min for the proto-oncogenic and mutant peptides, respectively. The decay constants were determined by integrating cross-peak volumes and fitting the data to a single exponential decay. The curve fitting was performed using the program Origin (version 6.1, Origin Lab Corporation). Gel Electrophoresis—Neu peptides were dissolved and incubated in standard loading buffer (30Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar) at 42 °C for 30 min and run on a 16.5% Tris-tricine gel (31Schägger H. Schägger H. Von Jagow G. A Practical Guide to Membrane Protein Purification. Academic Press, San Diego1994Google Scholar). The gel was stained with Coomassie Brilliant Blue. There have been three reported NMR studies on peptides corresponding to the TM domain of Neu in solution, all in TFE (19Goetz M. Carlotti C. Bontems F. Dufourc E.J. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 6534-6540Google Scholar, 20Houliston R.S. Hodges R.S. Sharom F.J. Davis J.H. FEBS Lett. 2003; 535: 39-43Google Scholar, 32Gullick W.J. Bottomley A.C. Lofts F.J. Doak D.G. Mulvey D. Newman R. Crumpton M.J. Sternberg M.J. Campbell I.D. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 43-48Google Scholar). This is a popular membrane mimetic solvent used to characterize the secondary structure of TM protein fragments; however, because tertiary interactions are generally disrupted, this solvent could not be used to investigate, for instance, the dimeric structure of the peptides. The 1H-NMR-derived monomeric structures of proto-oncogenic and mutant forms of the Neu peptides were found to be very similar in TFE (20Houliston R.S. Hodges R.S. Sharom F.J. Davis J.H. FEBS Lett. 2003; 535: 39-43Google Scholar, 32Gullick W.J. Bottomley A.C. Lofts F.J. Doak D.G. Mulvey D. Newman R. Crumpton M.J. Sternberg M.J. Campbell I.D. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 43-48Google Scholar). This contradicts an early theoretical investigation, which predicted that the favored conformation of the monomeric form of the proto-oncogenic receptor would be kinked at the mutation site, whereas the mutant form would adopt a canonical α-helix structure (33Brandt-Rauf P.W. Pincus M.R. Chen J.M. J. Protein Chem. 1989; 8: 749-756Google Scholar, 34Brandt-Rauf P.W. Rackovsky S. Pincus M.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 8660-8664Google Scholar). Solid-state NMR studies of Neu peptides in bilayers have also demonstrated that both forms of the receptor are likely helical at the mutation site, although these measurements were made on what were presumed to be dimeric forms of the peptides (15Smith S.O. Smith C. Shekar S. Peersen O. Ziliox M. Aimoto S. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 9321-9332Google Scholar). The heterogeneous nature of a micellar system reflects that of a lipid bilayer more accurately than do organic solvents and, consequently, is generally viewed as a more suitable membrane mimetic environment. Stable tertiary interactions can form in micelles, which enables the potential characterization of interhelical interactions between separate TM domains (35MacKenzie K.R. Prestegard J.H. Engelman D.M. Science. 1997; 276: 131-133Google Scholar), and, in cases where the protein/micelle complex remains relatively small, standard solution state NMR techniques can be applied to investigate both protein structure and dynamics. Several investigations of small membrane-associated proteins and TM fragments from larger proteins have been reported in micelles (reviewed in Ref. 36Damberg P. Jarvet J. Graslund A. Methods Enzymol. 2001; 339: 271-285Google Scholar). The effectiveness of micellar systems for NMR studies of membrane proteins is often hindered, however, by poor resolution, spectra that are not generally reproducible, and peptide aggregation (reviewed in Ref. 37Opella S.J. Ma C. Marassi F.M. Methods Enzymol. 2001; 339: 285-313Google Scholar). CD Spectroscopy—The CD spectra of proto-oncogenic and mutant Neu peptides dispersed in SDS and DPC micelles are presented in Fig. 1; for comparative purposes, spectra obtained in the solvent TFE are included in the figure as well. In all three solution conditions, both forms of the peptide are predominantly α-helical, as was predicted by using both a deconvolution algorithm (24Bohm G. Muhr R. Jaenicke R. Protein Eng. 1992; 5: 191-195Google Scholar) and the value of [Θ]222 (25Chang C.T. Wu C.S. Yang J.T. Anal. Biochem. 1978; 91: 13-31Google Scholar). The predicted α-helical percentages are higher when a deconvolution algorithm was used than when the predictions were based on [Θ]222; helical estimates for the different solution conditions studied range from 75 to 85% when obtained using the former method versus 60 to 65% when using the latter. The NMR spectral resolution of both peptides in micelles was significantly improved at pH values close to 4, so we obtained CD profiles in micelles at both neutral and acidic pH. Within the error associated with the technique, the α-helical content of the peptides does not appear to change between pH 4 and 7. The degree of interaction between two helical peptides can be estimated by using CD spectroscopy based on the [Θ]222:[Θ]208 ratio; a value of 1 is expected for helices that are completely associated, whereas monomeric helices exhibit a ratio of 0.8 (38Lau S.Y. Taneja A.K. Hodges R.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 13253-13261Google Scholar). An examination of the CD profiles reveals that there is a lower molar ellipticity at 208 nm in TFE than in micelles, which produces a different [Θ]222: [Θ]208 ratio in the two environments. The ratio is very close to 0.8 for both peptides in TFE, which is consistent with the notion that they exist predominantly as monomers in this solvent. In micelles, the [Θ]222: [Θ]208 ratio ranges between 0.85 and 0.9 for both forms of the peptide. This finding indicates that, within this environment, there is some level of association between the peptides. A comparison of the ratios obtained in micelles for the two peptides does not indicate that one form of the TM domain is more predisposed to dimeric interactions than the other. NMR Spectroscopy—Our analysis of the CD profiles suggests that both Neu peptides display similar levels of helicity and dimeric interactions in SDS and DPC micelles. We initially attempted to assign resonances to the Neu peptides dispersed in SDS micelles and, for this purpose, acquired spectra over a range of temperatures and solution pHs. Unfortunately, we were unable to make many assignments in this detergent, in particular, for residues close to the N terminus of the peptides where, in some samples, there appeared to be a lack of detectable signals for several resonances. For this reason, we attempted to characterize the peptides in DPC micelles. In this detergent we were able to obtain better spectral resolution with no apparent loss of signal from residues in the N-terminal region of the molecules. Spectra with the best resolution were acquired at relatively high temperatures and at low solution pHs. This has also been the case for studies of other membrane-bound proteins in detergent micelles (37Opella S.J. Ma C. Marassi F.M. Methods Enzymol. 2001; 339: 285-313Google Scholar). Even with the improved spectra obtained in DPC, there was significant overlap of peaks in the crucial amide fingerprint region, and we were not able to fully assign all of the backbone 1H resonances in either form of the peptide using standard two-dimensional homonuclear correlation spectra. To help in this process, we synthesized peptides with 15N amide labels at Val-6, Ala-11, Gly-15, Phe-19, Leu-22, and Gly-27 and used the proton assignments obtained from 15N-resolved spectra as points of departure from which to proceed with the sequential assignment of the other resonances in the peptide. In the final analysis, we were not able to unambiguously assign several resonances at the ends of the peptides. However, these residues are not believed to be found within the helical portion of the TM domain in the native protein. In general, the spectra acquired in DPC were fairly reproducible, although there was some variability in the chemical shift of amide resonances (up to 0.1 ppm), even when an effort was made to prepare samples in a consistent manner. Once dispersed in DPC, the peptides were fairly stable, with little loss of signal detected in samples that were up to a month old. With respect to the chemical shift of amide resonances, spectra obtained for the proto-oncogenic form of the peptide in DPC were noticeably different from those obtained with the mutant form. This is illustrated in 1H–15N HSQC spectra of the hexa-(15N)-labeled peptides presented in Fig. 2. Once again, for comparative purposes we have presented spectra acquired in the solvent TFE as well, where the peptides adopt very similar structures and display similar chemical shifts in this homogenous environment (20Houliston R.S. Hodges R.S. Sharom F.J. Davis J.H. FEBS Lett. 2003; 535: 39-43Google Scholar). This trend is also observed in comparing the HSQC spectra of the peptides in TFE, where there are only small differences in the position of the cross-peaks in either the proton or the nitrogen dimension (Fig. 2, A and B). In contrast, there is a significant variation in the position of the cross-peaks in the HSQC spectra for the two peptides dispersed in DPC micelles (Fig. 2, C and D). This difference is most pronounced for residues close to the N-terminal region of the peptide. In Fig. 3, the NH-CHα region from NOESY spectra of Neu peptides is presented, with arrows drawn to show the sequential connectivities between the NH and CHα resonances in the peptides. As noted above, there is considerable overlap of cross-peaks in these spectra, which led to difficulty in making several resonance assignments. Although there are differences in the chemical shifts of amide protons throughout the entire length of the molecules, a noticeable trend is observed in comparing the spectra of proto-oncogenic and mutant Neu peptides in DPC; the amide peak dispersion pattern is similar for residues between Phe-19 and Ile-30 but is significantly different between Val-6 and Thr-12. Because of the change in primary sequence, the position of amide resonances close to the mutation site would be expected to exhibit variability. The chemical shift of an amide proton is very sensitive to its chemical environment (39Williamson M.P. Biopolymers. 1990; 29: 1423-1431Google Scholar) and is dictated by both the structural element it is found in and its relative solvent exposure. Our spectra clearly demonstrate that the structural environment of peptides within the micelle is different, and this difference is most pronounced in the N-terminal region of the peptide.Fig. 3NOESY spectra corresponding to the NH-CHα region of Neu peptides. Single-letter amino acid abbreviations are used with position numbers.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) The optical CD data not only indicate that the two forms of TM Neu peptides adopt similar levels of helicity in detergent micelles, but that these levels are similar to those observed in TFE, where it was determined previously that the adopted α-helical structure incorporates residues from Val-6 through to Ile-30 (20Houliston R.S. Hodges R.S. Sharom F.J. Davis J.H. FEBS Lett. 2003; 535: 39-43Google Scholar). Even though there are significant differences in the chemical shifts of amide protons in DPC, the NMR data are consistent with the formation of a helical structure in residues 6 though 30 in both forms of the peptide. An examination of the CHα chemical shifts for these residues indicates they are uniformly upfield of random coil values, which is a strong indication of α-helix formation (39Williamson M.P. Biopolymers. 1990; 29: 1423-1431Google Scholar). The CHα chemical shift deviations from random coil values (CSDs) for residues 6 through 30 are presented as a histogram in Fig. 4A for both peptides. Once again, it can be seen in this figure that, for the residues in the C-terminal region of the peptide, the CHα CSDs are almost identical. There are observable differences in the histogram, however, for residues close to the N terminus (e.g. Thr-9, Ala-11, and Thr-12), and, where differences exist, the CHα CSDs are more negative for residues found in the proto-oncogenic peptide. This is potentially indicative of a more rigid helical structure in this region for this form of the molecule. It should be noted that, among the residues that we were able to assign at the ends of the peptides, the CHα shifts are very close to random coil values (data not shown). The NOE connectivity profile is presented for both peptides in Fig. 4B. Even in light of the considerable overlap of peaks in the NOESY spectra, which prevented the assignment of several peaks, the pattern for both peptides is typical of an α-helix, with several Hαi-NHi+3, Hαi-NHi+4, and Hβi-NHi+1 contacts for residues between 6 and 30. Curiously, we observed no NHi-NHi+1 contacts in the mutant form of the peptide in the N-terminal region, whereas several were observed in the protooncogenic peptide.
